text: Motion is a relative concept. What does this imply?

options.text: An object is always in motion.
An object's motion is described with respect to a reference point or surroundings.
Motion can only be described by complex mathematical equations.
An object is always at rest.

explanation: Motion is relative because the state of motion or rest of an object depends on the observer's frame of reference or the surroundings. For example, a person sitting in a moving bus is at rest relative to other passengers but in motion relative to a person standing on the road. (Page 11)

text: What is the primary difference between distance and displacement?

options.text: Distance is a vector quantity, while displacement is a scalar quantity.
Distance is the minimum path between two points, while displacement is the actual path travelled.
Distance is the actual path travelled, while displacement is the minimum distance between the starting and finishing points.
Both distance and displacement are always equal.

explanation: Distance is the length of the actual path travelled by an object in motion, whereas displacement is the minimum distance (straight line) between the starting and finishing points. Distance is scalar, displacement is vector. (Page 12)

text: If a car travels from point P to point Q and then returns to point P, what is its displacement?

options.text: Twice the distance between P and Q.
The distance between P and Q.
Half the distance between P and Q.

explanation: Displacement is the minimum distance between the starting and finishing points. Since the car starts at P and finishes at P, its displacement is zero. (Page 12)

text: Which of the following quantities are vectors: distance, speed, velocity, time, displacement?
explanation: Velocity and displacement are vector quantities as they have both magnitude and direction. Distance, speed, and time are scalar quantities. (Page 12)

text: What is the SI unit of speed and velocity?
explanation: The SI unit of speed and velocity is metres per second (m/s). The CGS unit is cm/s. (Page 12)

text: Sheetal takes 5 minutes to reach Sangeeta's house (500m away) and then 24 minutes to reach school (1200m from Sangeeta's house). What is Sheetal's average speed for the entire journey from her house to school?
explanation: Total distance = 500 m + 1200 m = 1700 m. Total time = 5 min + 24 min = 29 min. Average speed = Total distance / Total time = 1700 m / 29 min ≈ 58.6 m/minute. (Page 13)

text: When does the velocity of an object change?

options.text: Only when its direction of motion changes.
When either its speed or direction of motion changes, or both change.
Velocity of an object never changes.

explanation: Velocity is a vector quantity, depending on both speed and direction. It changes if speed changes, direction changes, or both change. (Page 13)

text: An object is said to be in uniform linear motion if it covers:

options.text: Unequal distances in equal time intervals.
Equal distances in unequal time intervals.
Equal distances in equal time intervals.
Unequal distances in unequal time intervals.

explanation: An object is said to be moving with uniform speed (or in uniform linear motion if direction is constant) if it covers equal distances in equal time intervals. (Page 14)

text: What is acceleration?

options.text: The rate of change of distance.
The rate of change of speed.
The rate of change of velocity.
The rate of change of displacement.

explanation: Acceleration is defined as the rate of change of velocity. It is a vector quantity. (Page 15)

text: If an object starts from rest, its initial velocity (u) is:
explanation: When an object is at rest in the beginning of its motion, its initial velocity is zero. (Page 15)

text: Negative acceleration is also known as:
explanation: When the velocity of an object decreases with time, it has negative acceleration, which is also called deceleration or retardation. (Page 15)

text: What does the slope of a distance-time graph for uniform motion represent?
explanation: For uniform motion, the distance-time graph is a straight line. The slope of this straight line indicates the speed of the object. (Page 16)

text: A train is moving with a uniform velocity of 60 km/hour. How much distance will it cover between 2 and 4 hours?
explanation: The time interval is 4 - 2 = 2 hours. Distance = velocity × time = 60 km/hr × 2 hr = 120 km. This can also be found from the area under the velocity-time graph. (Page 16)

text: What does the area under a velocity-time graph represent for an object in uniform acceleration?

options.text: The final velocity of the object.
The time taken for the motion.

explanation: The area under the velocity-time graph gives the displacement of the object during that time interval. For uniform acceleration, this area can be a trapezium or a combination of a rectangle and a triangle. (Page 17, 18)

text: Which equation of motion describes the relation between velocity and time for a uniformly accelerated object?
explanation: The first equation of motion, v = u + at, describes the relationship between final velocity (v), initial velocity (u), acceleration (a), and time (t). (Page 18)

text: The equation s = ut + (1/2)at² relates which quantities?
explanation: The second equation of motion, s = ut + (1/2)at², relates displacement (s), initial velocity (u), time (t), and acceleration (a). (Page 18)

text: In uniform circular motion, which of the following remains constant?
explanation: In uniform circular motion, the speed of the object remains constant, but its velocity continuously changes due to the change in direction. It is an accelerated motion. (Page 19)

text: An athlete running on a circular track covers 400 m in 25 s and returns to the starting position. What is her average velocity?
explanation: Average velocity is total displacement divided by total time. Since the athlete returns to the original position, the total displacement is zero. Therefore, the average velocity is 0 m/s. (Page 21)

text: Newton's first law of motion is also known as:
explanation: Newton's first law of motion describes the property of inertia, which is the inability of an object to change its state of motion on its own. Hence, it is also called the law of inertia. (Page 22)

text: What is momentum (P) defined as?
explanation: Momentum (P) is the product of an object's mass (m) and its velocity (v). It is a vector quantity. (Page 23)

text: The SI unit of momentum is:
explanation: The SI unit of momentum is kilogram-metre per second (kg m/s). The CGS unit is gram-centimetre per second (g cm/s). (Page 23)

text: Newton's second law of motion states that the rate of change of momentum is proportional to:
explanation: Newton's second law states that 'The rate of change of momentum is proportional to the applied force and the change of momentum occurs in the direction of the force.' This leads to F = ma. (Page 23)

text: What is the SI unit of force?
explanation: The SI unit of force is Newton (N). 1 Newton is the force necessary to cause an acceleration of 1 m/s² in an object of mass 1 kg. (Page 24)

text: Newton's third law of motion states that:

options.text: Every object continues in its state of rest or uniform motion unless an external force acts on it.
The rate of change of momentum is proportional to the applied force.
Every action force has an equal and opposite reaction force which acts simultaneously.
The total momentum of an isolated system remains constant.

explanation: Newton's third law states that 'Every action force has an equal and opposite reaction force which acts simultaneously.' (Page 24)

text: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of action and reaction forces described by Newton's third law?

options.text: They act on the same object.
They are equal in magnitude and opposite in direction.

explanation: Action and reaction forces act on different objects. They do not act on the same object and hence cannot cancel each other's effect. (Page 24)

text: The law of conservation of momentum states that if no external force acts on two interacting objects:
explanation: The law of conservation of momentum states that 'When no external force acts on two interacting objects, their total momentum remains constant. It does not change.' (Page 25)

text: A bullet of mass m₁ is fired from a gun of mass m₂ with velocity v₁. The gun recoils with velocity v₂. According to the law of conservation of momentum, if the initial momentum was zero:
explanation: If the initial momentum (gun + bullet at rest) is zero, the final total momentum must also be zero. So, m₁v₁ (momentum of bullet) + m₂v₂ (momentum of gun) = 0. This implies m₂v₂ = -m₁v₁, where the negative sign indicates opposite direction. (Page 25)

text:
Consider the following statements:
1. Distance is always positive or zero.
2. Displacement can be positive, negative, or zero.
3. If an object returns to its starting point, its displacement is zero but distance travelled may not be zero.
How many of the above statements are true?
explanation:
1. Distance is a scalar quantity representing the length of the path, so it's always non-negative. (True) 
2. Displacement is a vector quantity and can be positive, negative (indicating direction), or zero. (True) 
3. If an object returns to its starting point, its final position is the same as its initial position, so displacement is zero. However, it has travelled a certain path, so distance is non-zero (unless it didn't move at all). (True) (Page 12)

text:
Assertion (A): An object in uniform circular motion experiences acceleration.
Reason (R): In uniform circular motion, the velocity of the object changes continuously due to change in direction.

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

explanation: An object in uniform circular motion has constant speed, but its direction of velocity is continuously changing (it's always tangential to the circle). Since velocity is changing, there is an acceleration (centripetal acceleration). Thus, both A and R are true, and R correctly explains A. (Page 19, 20)

text: If the velocity of an object moving in a straight line changes from 10 m/s to 20 m/s in 5 seconds, what is its acceleration?
explanation: Initial velocity u = 10 m/s, final velocity v = 20 m/s, time t = 5 s. Acceleration a = (v-u)/t = (20-10)/5 = 10/5 = 2 m/s². (Page 15)

text: Which phenomenon is an example of Newton's first law of motion (inertia)?

options.text: A ball thrown upwards eventually falling down.
Passengers in a bus lurch forward when the bus suddenly stops.
The recoil of a gun when a bullet is fired.

explanation: When a bus suddenly stops, the passengers tend to continue their state of motion due to inertia, causing them to lurch forward. This is an example of inertia of motion. (Page 22)

text: A force of 10 N acts on an object of mass 2 kg. What is the acceleration produced?
explanation: According to Newton's second law, F = ma. So, a = F/m = 10 N / 2 kg = 5 m/s². (Page 23)

text: When a person jumps from a boat to the shore, the boat moves backwards. This is an example of:

options.text: The law of conservation of energy.

explanation: The person exerts a force (action) on the boat to push themselves forward. The boat exerts an equal and opposite force (reaction) on the person, and also moves backward due to the person's push. This illustrates Newton's third law. (Page 24)

text: The speed of a car changes from 36 km/hr to 72 km/hr in 10 seconds. What is its acceleration in m/s²?
explanation: Initial velocity u = 36 km/hr = 36 * (1000/3600) m/s = 10 m/s. Final velocity v = 72 km/hr = 72 * (1000/3600) m/s = 20 m/s. Time t = 10 s. Acceleration a = (v-u)/t = (20-10)/10 = 10/10 = 1 m/s². (Page 15 - concept, conversion required)

text:
Consider these statements about uniform circular motion:
1. The speed of the object is constant.
2. The velocity of the object is constant.
3. The object is accelerating.
How many of these statements are true?
explanation:
1. True: In uniform circular motion, speed is constant. 
2. False: Velocity changes because direction changes. 
3. True: Because velocity changes, there is acceleration (centripetal). So, statements 1 and 3 are true. (Page 19, 20)

text:
Assertion (A): When a carpet is beaten with a stick, dust particles are removed.
Reason (R): This is an example of inertia of rest, where the dust particles tend to remain at rest while the carpet moves.

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

explanation: Beating a carpet sets the carpet in motion. The dust particles, due to inertia of rest, tend to remain in their state of rest. As the carpet moves away, the dust particles fall off. Both A and R are true, and R correctly explains A. (Relates to Page 22 concept)

text: If an object moves with a constant velocity of 5 m/s for 10 seconds, its acceleration is:
explanation: Constant velocity means there is no change in velocity. Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity. Therefore, if velocity is constant, acceleration is zero. (Page 15)

text: Which of the following is NOT a vector quantity?
explanation: Speed is a scalar quantity as it only has magnitude. Displacement, velocity, and acceleration are vector quantities as they have both magnitude and direction. (Page 12)

text: A ball is thrown vertically upwards. At its highest point, its velocity is:
explanation: When a ball is thrown vertically upwards, its velocity decreases due to gravity. At the highest point, its velocity momentarily becomes zero before it starts to fall down. (General physics concept related to motion under gravity, extension of chapter concepts)

text: The slope of a velocity-time graph for an object in uniform motion (constant velocity) is:
explanation: For uniform motion (constant velocity), the velocity-time graph is a horizontal line parallel to the time axis. The slope of a horizontal line is zero, indicating zero acceleration. (Page 16)

text: Which of these describes a body experiencing non-uniform acceleration?

options.text: Its velocity changes by equal amounts in equal time intervals.
Its velocity changes by unequal amounts in equal time intervals.
It covers equal distances in equal time intervals.

explanation: If the velocity changes by unequal amounts in equal time intervals, the object is said to be in non-uniform acceleration. (Page 15)

text: An aeroplane taxies on the runway for 30 s with an acceleration of 3.2 m/s² before taking off. If it starts from rest, what distance does it cover on the runway?
If an object is moving with a constant speed in a straight line, its acceleration is:
explanation: If an object is moving with constant speed in a straight line, its velocity is constant. Since acceleration is the rate of change of velocity, its acceleration is zero. (Page 15)

text: The tendency of an object to resist a change in its state of motion is called:
explanation: Inertia is the property of an object by virtue of which it resists any change in its state of rest or of uniform motion. (Page 22)

text:
Consider the following statements regarding forces:
1. A force can change the speed of an object.
2. A force can change the direction of motion of an object.
3. A force can change the shape of an object.
How many of the above statements are true?
explanation: A force can cause a change in speed (acceleration/deceleration), a change in direction, and also a change in shape (deformation) of an object. All three statements are effects of force. (General understanding of force, related to chapter context)

text:
Assertion (A): A cricketer moves his hands backwards while catching a fast cricket ball.
Reason (R): He does so to increase the time of impact, thereby reducing the force exerted by the ball on his hands.

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

explanation: By moving his hands backward, the cricketer increases the time (Δt) over which the momentum of the ball changes to zero. Since Force = (Change in momentum) / Δt, increasing Δt reduces the force of impact. This is an application of Newton's second law (impulse-momentum). Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation. (Application of concepts on Page 23)

text: The speed of revolution of the earth around the sun is approximately:
explanation: The speed of revolution of the earth around the sun is about 29770 m/s. (Page 13)

text: If a body covers unequal distances in equal intervals of time, it is said to be in:
explanation: If an object covers unequal distances in equal time intervals, it is said to be moving with non-uniform speed, or simply in non-uniform motion. (Page 14)

text: Which of Newton's laws of motion is related to the definition of force as that which changes or tends to change the state of rest or of uniform motion of a body?
explanation: Newton's First Law defines force qualitatively. It states that an object continues to remain at rest or in a state of uniform motion along a straight line unless an external unbalanced force acts on it. This implies force is what causes a change in the state of motion. (Page 22)

text: A SONAR station uses which type of waves to determine distance, direction, and speed of underwater objects?
explanation: SONAR (Sound Navigation and Ranging) uses ultrasonic sound waves to detect and locate underwater objects. (This information is in Chapter 12, page 133 of the same textbook, but the question mentions SONAR station on page 9, making it slightly out of the direct text of chapter 1 but related to science and technology in general for this grade level)

text: What is the initial velocity of a kangaroo that jumps 2.5 m vertically, assuming g = 9.8 m/s² and its final velocity at the highest point is 0 m/s?
explanation: Given s = 2.5 m, v = 0 m/s, a = -9.8 m/s² (upward motion). Using v² = u² + 2as: 0² = u² + 2(-9.8)(2.5) => 0 = u² - 49 => u² = 49 => u = 7 m/s. (Page 21)

text: If the velocity of an object does not change with time, its acceleration is:
explanation: If the velocity of the object does not change with time, it has zero acceleration. (Page 15)

text: The second equation of motion can be derived from the area of which shape on a velocity-time graph for uniform acceleration, starting from initial velocity u?

options.text: A trapezium (or a rectangle and a triangle)

explanation: The displacement 's' is given by the area of quadrangle DOEB (a trapezium) on the velocity-time graph. This area can be split into a rectangle (DOEA) and a triangle (DAB), leading to s = area(rectangle DOEA) + area(triangle DAB) which results in s = ut + (1/2)at². (Page 18)

text: An object moving along a circular path of radius 'r' takes time 't' to return to its starting position. Its speed is given by:
explanation: The distance covered in one revolution is the circumference of the circle, which is 2πr. Speed = Distance / Time = 2πr / t. (Page 20)

text: If a coin is placed on a rotating circular disc and the disc is moved at higher speed, the coin is thrown off. In which direction is the coin thrown off?
explanation: The coin will be thrown off in the direction of the tangent to the circular path at the point where it leaves the disc. This is due to inertia of direction. (Page 20)

text: In the absence of an external unbalanced force, an object will:

options.text: Continue in its state of rest or of uniform motion in a straight line.

explanation: This is a restatement of Newton's first law of motion. (Page 22)

text: Which of the following scenarios best illustrates balanced forces?

options.text: A car accelerating on a highway.
A book resting on a table.
A ball falling freely under gravity.

explanation: A book resting on a table is in equilibrium. The downward force of gravity is balanced by the upward normal force from the table. Thus, the net force is zero. (Page 22)

text: If two forces acting on an object are equal in magnitude but opposite in direction, and their line of action is the same, the net force is:

options.text: Twice the magnitude of one force.
Half the magnitude of one force.

explanation: If two forces are equal and opposite and act along the same line, they are balanced forces, and their net effect (net force) is zero. (Conceptual understanding related to Page 22)

text: 1 Dyne is the CGS unit of force. 1 Newton is equal to how many Dynes?
explanation: 1 Newton = 1 kg × 1 m/s² = (1000 g) × (100 cm/s²) = 100000 g cm/s² = 10⁵ Dynes. (Derived from definitions on Page 24)

text:
Assertion (A): The total momentum before collision is equal to the total momentum after collision if no external force acts.
Reason (R): Momentum is a vector quantity.

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

explanation: Assertion A is the statement of the law of conservation of momentum. Reason R is true; momentum is indeed a vector quantity. However, the fact that momentum is a vector doesn't directly explain why it's conserved in the absence of external forces. The conservation law is a fundamental principle derived from Newton's laws. (Page 23, 25)

text: Which of the following has the largest inertia?

options.text: Your school bag full of books

explanation: Inertia is related to the mass of an object. The greater the mass, the greater the inertia. A school bag full of books has significantly more mass than a pin, pen, or ink bottle. (Related to concepts on Page 22)

text: If the initial velocity of an object is u, final velocity is v, time taken is t, and acceleration is a, which equation is INCORRECT?
explanation: The correct formula for acceleration is a = (v-u)/t. The options a, b, and c are the three standard equations of motion. (Page 18)

text: A body is moving with uniform velocity. Which of the following statements is true?

options.text: Its speed is constant, but direction may change.
Its speed may change, but direction is constant.
Both its speed and direction are constant.

explanation: Uniform velocity means that both the speed (magnitude of velocity) and the direction of motion are constant. If either changes, the velocity is not uniform. (Page 14 concept)

text: What is the CGS unit of force?
explanation: In the CGS system, the unit of force is a dyne. 1 dyne = 1 g × 1 cm/s². (Page 24)

text:
Consider the following statements about action-reaction pairs:
1. They always act on two different bodies.
2. They are always equal in magnitude.
3. They always act in the same direction.
How many of these statements are true?
explanation:
1. True: Action and reaction forces act on different bodies. 
2. True: They are equal in magnitude. 
3. False: They act in opposite directions. So, statements 1 and 2 are true. (Page 24)

text: The physical state of a conductor, relevant to Ohm's law, includes its:

options.text: Length, area of cross-section, temperature, and material.

explanation: Ohm's law states that if the physical state of a conductor remains constant... The physical state refers to its length, area of cross-section, temperature, and the material it is made of. (This is from Chapter 3, page 34, but Ohm's law is a fundamental concept in physics often introduced earlier or assumed knowledge for motion context in some curricula.)

text: An object starts from rest and accelerates uniformly at 2 m/s² for 5 seconds. What is its final velocity?
explanation: Given u=0, a=2 m/s², t=5s. Using v = u + at = 0 + 2*5 = 10 m/s. (Page 18)

text: A car moving at 20 m/s applies brakes and comes to rest in 4 seconds. What is its deceleration?
explanation: Initial velocity u = 20 m/s, final velocity v = 0 m/s, time t = 4 s. Acceleration a = (v-u)/t = (0-20)/4 = -20/4 = -5 m/s². Deceleration is 5 m/s². (Page 15)

text: If the net force acting on an object is zero, the object will:

options.text: Either be at rest or move with constant velocity.

explanation: According to Newton's first law, if the net force is zero (balanced forces), the object will maintain its state of rest or of uniform motion (constant velocity) in a straight line. (Page 22)

text: The 'impulse' of a force is defined as:
explanation: Impulse is defined as the product of force and the time interval for which the force acts. It is also equal to the change in momentum of the object. (This is an extension of Newton's second law, related to concepts on Page 23, but not explicitly defined in chapter 1 of this PDF.)

text: What is the type of inertia that resists a change in an object's direction of motion?
explanation: Inertia of direction is the tendency of an object to resist any change in its direction of motion. For example, when a car takes a sharp turn, passengers tend to lean outwards due to inertia of direction. (This is a specific type of inertia, related to the general concept on Page 22, but not explicitly differentiated in this PDF.)

text: If the distance-time graph of an object is a curve, then the object is in:
explanation: A straight line distance-time graph indicates uniform motion. A curved distance-time graph indicates that the object is covering unequal distances in equal time intervals, which is non-uniform motion. (Page 16)

text: A person is standing in a lift. When the lift accelerates upwards, the apparent weight of the person will:
explanation: When the lift accelerates upwards, the normal reaction force exerted by the floor of the lift on the person increases. This normal force is what we perceive as apparent weight. So, the apparent weight increases. (Application of Newton's second law, out of PDF for this chapter).

text: In the context of Newton's first law, 'unbalanced force' means:

options.text: A single force acting on the object.
The net force acting on the object is not zero.
Forces that are perpendicular to each other.
Forces that act for a very short time.

explanation: An unbalanced force implies that the vector sum of all forces (net force) acting on the object is not zero, leading to a change in its state of motion. (Page 22)

text: Which of the following is a correct statement?

options.text: Displacement can be greater than distance.
If displacement is zero, distance must be zero.
Distance is always less than or equal to displacement.
Displacement is less than or equal to distance.

explanation: Displacement is the shortest distance between two points, while distance is the actual path length. Therefore, the magnitude of displacement is always less than or equal to the distance travelled. (Page 12)

text:
Assertion (A): When a gun is fired, it recoils.
Reason (R): The gun pushes the bullet forward (action), and the bullet pushes the gun backward (reaction) with an equal and opposite force.

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

explanation: The recoil of a gun is a classic example of Newton's third law. The expanding gases exert a force on the bullet (action), and the bullet exerts an equal and opposite force on the gun (reaction), causing it to recoil. It's also explained by conservation of momentum. Both A and R are true, and R is a correct explanation. (Page 24, 25)

text:
Consider the following statements about inertia:
1. Inertia depends on the mass of the object.
2. Lighter objects have more inertia than heavier objects.
3. Inertia is the resistance to change in velocity.
How many statements are false?
explanation:
1. True: Inertia is directly proportional to mass. 
2. False: Heavier objects have more inertia. 
3. True: Inertia is the resistance to change in the state of motion (which includes velocity). So, only statement 2 is false. (Page 22)

text: A force changes the velocity of a body from 5 m/s to 15 m/s in 2 seconds. If the mass of the body is 2 kg, the magnitude of the force is:
explanation: Acceleration a = (v-u)/t = (15-5)/2 = 10/2 = 5 m/s². Force F = ma = 2 kg * 5 m/s² = 10 N. (Page 23)

text: The third equation of motion v² = u² + 2as relates:

options.text: Initial velocity, final velocity, and time.
Final velocity, initial velocity, acceleration, and displacement.

explanation: The equation v² = u² + 2as relates final velocity (v), initial velocity (u), acceleration (a), and displacement (s). It is also known as the displacement-velocity relation. (Page 18)

text: Which scientist is credited with first measuring speed as distance/time?
explanation: The first scientist to measure speed as the distance/time was Galileo. (Page 13)

text: If a body is at rest, its velocity is zero. Can it have non-zero acceleration?

options.text: Yes, if it is momentarily at rest but about to move (e.g., a ball at the top of its trajectory).
Only if it has zero mass.

explanation: A body can have zero velocity and non-zero acceleration simultaneously. For example, when a ball is thrown upwards, at its highest point, its velocity is zero, but it is still accelerating downwards due to gravity. (Out of PDF for this chapter, tests deeper understanding of acceleration).

text: Seatbelts in cars are designed to protect passengers during sudden stops. Which law of motion is primarily involved in this safety feature?
explanation: During a sudden stop, the passenger's body tends to continue moving forward due to inertia of motion. The seatbelt applies a force to counteract this motion and prevent injury. (Application of concept on Page 22)

text: What does '1 Newton' of force signify?

options.text: The force that gives a 1 kg mass an acceleration of 9.8 m/s².
The force that gives a 1 g mass an acceleration of 1 cm/s².
The force that gives a 1 kg mass an acceleration of 1 m/s².
The force required to lift a 1 kg mass.

explanation: One Newton (N) is defined as the force necessary to cause an acceleration of 1 m/s² in an object of mass 1 kg. (Page 24)

text: If an object moves from point A to point B along a straight line and then returns from B to A, and the distance AB is 100m, the total distance covered is ____ and total displacement is ____.
explanation: Total distance = distance from A to B + distance from B to A = 100m + 100m = 200m. Since the object returns to its starting point A, the total displacement is 0m. (Page 12)

text: The law of conservation of momentum is a direct consequence of which of Newton's laws?

options.text: Newton's Third Law (and implicitly the Second Law)
It is independent of Newton's laws.

explanation: The law of conservation of momentum can be derived from Newton's second and third laws. The PDF mentions it as a corollary to Newton's third law. For a system of two interacting particles, the third law implies internal forces cancel, and the second law then leads to conservation of total momentum if external forces are zero. (Page 25)

text: If the number of sides of a polygon path increases and approaches infinity, the path becomes a:
explanation: As the number of sides of a polygon increases, it more closely approximates a circle. When the number of sides approaches infinity, the polygon becomes a circle. (Page 20)

text: A car travels at a constant speed of 60 km/h. Is it accelerating?

options.text: Only if it is moving in a straight line.
Yes, if it is turning (e.g., moving on a circular path).

explanation: If the car is travelling at a constant speed but is turning (changing direction), its velocity is changing, and therefore it is accelerating (centripetal acceleration). If it's moving in a straight line at constant speed, its acceleration is zero. (Conceptual, related to Page 15, 19)

text: Consider the equations of motion. Which equation would be most suitable to find the final velocity of an object if its initial velocity, acceleration, and displacement are known, but time is not?
explanation: The equation v² = u² + 2as directly relates final velocity (v), initial velocity (u), acceleration (a), and displacement (s), without involving time (t). (Page 18)

text: The 'change in momentum' of an object is equal to:
explanation: The impulse-momentum theorem states that the impulse of a force acting on an object is equal to the change in momentum of that object. Impulse = FΔt = Δp. (Out of PDF chapter 1, advanced concept related to Newton's 2nd Law)

text:
Assertion (A): If an object is thrown upwards, the time taken to reach the maximum height is equal to the time taken to fall back to the initial position (neglecting air resistance).
Reason (R): The acceleration due to gravity is constant both during upward and downward motion.

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

explanation: For projectile motion under constant gravity (neglecting air resistance), the motion is symmetrical. The time of ascent equals the time of descent. This is because the magnitude of acceleration (g) is constant throughout the motion. Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation. (Application of equations of motion, general physics).

text: When an electric fan is switched off, it continues to rotate for some time. This is due to:

options.text: Electrical energy stored in the fan

explanation: The fan continues to rotate due to inertia of motion, which is its tendency to maintain its state of rotational motion. (Page 22, example 4)

text: Fruits fall from a tree when its branches are shaken. This is an example of:

options.text: Inertia of motion of the fruits.
Inertia of rest of the fruits.

explanation: When the branches are shaken, they are set into motion. The fruits, due to inertia of rest, tend to remain in their position of rest. This causes them to detach from the moving branches and fall. (Page 22, example 3)

text: A mass of 1 kg is equivalent to a weight of approximately (on Earth's surface):
explanation: Weight (W) is the force of gravity on an object, given by W = mg, where m is mass and g is acceleration due to gravity (approx. 9.8 m/s² on Earth). So, for 1 kg mass, W = 1 kg * 9.8 m/s² = 9.8 N. (General physics knowledge, related to force concepts in the chapter).

text: If a force F applied for time t changes the momentum of an object from p1 to p2, then according to Newton's second law:
explanation: Newton's second law states that force is the rate of change of momentum. So, F = (change in momentum) / time = (p2 - p1) / t. (Conceptual understanding from Page 23)

text: The path of a projectile fired at an angle to the horizontal (neglecting air resistance) is a:
explanation: The trajectory of a projectile under the influence of constant gravity (neglecting air resistance) is parabolic. (This is a standard physics concept related to motion, often studied alongside or after basic laws of motion. Out of PDF chapter 1).

text: Consider the following quantities: (i) Velocity, (ii) Speed, (iii) Acceleration, (iv) Distance, (v) Displacement. How many of these are vector quantities?
explanation: Velocity, Acceleration, and Displacement are vector quantities (have magnitude and direction). Speed and Distance are scalar quantities (have only magnitude). So, 3 are vector quantities. (Page 12, 15)

text: If an object undergoes uniform acceleration, its velocity-time graph will be:

options.text: A straight line parallel to the time axis.
A straight line inclined to the time axis.

explanation: For all uniformly accelerated motions, the velocity-time graph is a straight line inclined to the time axis. The slope of this line represents the uniform acceleration. (Page 17)

text: Which of the following is a correct statement regarding the motion of the tip of a second hand of a clock?

options.text: Its speed is constant and velocity is constant.
Its speed is variable and velocity is constant.
Its speed is constant but velocity is variable.
Its speed is variable and velocity is variable.

explanation: The tip of the second hand of a clock moves with constant speed, but its direction is continuously changing. Therefore, its velocity (which is speed + direction) is variable. This is an example of uniform circular motion. (Page 19)

text: A body of mass 5 kg has a momentum of 10 kg m/s. Its velocity is:
explanation: Momentum P = mv. So, velocity v = P/m = 10 kg m/s / 5 kg = 2 m/s. (Page 23)

text: The 'Reaction' force in Newton's Third Law:

options.text: Is always greater than the 'Action' force.
Acts on the same body as the 'Action' force.
Is equal in magnitude and opposite in direction to the 'Action' force, acting on a different body.

explanation: The reaction force is equal in magnitude and opposite in direction to the action force. Importantly, action and reaction forces act on different bodies and occur simultaneously. (Page 24)

text: When is work said to be done in physics?

options.text: When an object experiences a force, regardless of motion.
When a force applied on an object causes displacement of the object.
When an object is stationary but a force is acting on it.
When a person is thinking hard about a problem.

explanation: In physics, work is said to be done when a force applied on an object causes displacement of the object in the direction of the force. (Page 18)

text: What is the formula for work done when the displacement is in the direction of the applied force?
explanation: The work done by a force acting on an object is the product of the magnitude of the force and the displacement of the object in the direction of the force. Thus, Work = force × displacement. (Page 18)

text: If a child pulls a toy cart with a string, and the force is applied along the direction of the string while the cart moves horizontally, how is the work done calculated?

options.text: By multiplying the total force applied by the total distance moved.
By converting the applied force into the component acting along the direction of displacement.
By considering only the vertical component of the force.
Work done is always zero in this case.

explanation: When the force and displacement are not in the same direction, the component of the force acting along the direction of displacement (F₁ = F cos θ) is used to calculate work (W = F₁s = Fs cos θ). (Page 19)

text: What is the work done when the force and displacement are in the same direction (θ = 0°)?
explanation: When θ = 0°, cos θ = 1. Therefore, W = Fs cos θ = Fs(1) = Fs. This is positive work. (Page 19, 20)

text: What is the SI unit of work?
explanation: In the SI system, the unit of force is newton (N) and the unit of displacement is metre (m). Thus, the unit of work is newton-metre, which is called a joule (J). (Page 20)

text: One joule of work is done when:

options.text: A force of 1 dyne displaces an object by 1 cm.
A force of 1 newton displaces an object by 1 cm.
A force of 1 newton displaces an object by 1 metre in the direction of the force.
A force of 1 dyne displaces an object by 1 metre.

explanation: If a force of 1 newton displaces an object through 1 metre in the direction of the force, the amount of work done on the object is 1 joule. (Page 20)

text: What is the relationship between joule and erg?
explanation: We know that 1 newton = 10⁵ dyne and 1 m = 10² cm. Therefore, 1 joule = 1 N × 1 m = 10⁵ dyne × 10² cm = 10⁷ dyne cm = 10⁷ erg. (Page 20)

text: When is the work done by a force considered negative?

options.text: When the force and displacement are in the same direction (θ = 0°).
When the force and displacement are perpendicular to each other (θ = 90°).
When the force and displacement are in opposite directions (θ = 180°).

explanation: When the force and the displacement are in opposite directions (θ = 180°), cos 180° = -1. So, W = -Fs, and the work done by the force is negative. (Page 20)

text: What is the work done by the gravitational force on an artificial satellite moving around the Earth in a circular orbit?
explanation: The gravitational force acting on the satellite is along the radius of the circle, and its displacement is along the tangent to the circle. Since the force and displacement are perpendicular to each other (θ = 90°), the work done by the gravitational force is zero. (Page 21)

text: The capacity of a body to perform work is called its:
explanation: The capacity of a body to perform work is called its energy. The units of work and energy are the same. (Page 22)

text: Which of the following is a form of mechanical energy?
explanation: Mechanical energy has two main forms: potential energy and kinetic energy. (Page 22)

text: The energy which an object has because of its motion is called its:
explanation: The energy which an object has because of its motion is called its kinetic energy. (Page 22)

text: What is the formula for kinetic energy (K.E.) of an object with mass 'm' and velocity 'v'?
explanation: The expression for kinetic energy is K.E. = ½ mv². (Page 23)

text: If the velocity of an object is doubled, its kinetic energy becomes:
explanation: Kinetic energy is proportional to the square of the velocity (K.E. ∝ v²). If velocity is doubled (2v), K.E. becomes ½ m(2v)² = ½ m(4v²) = 4 (½ mv²), which is four times the original K.E. (Page 23)

text: The energy stored in an object because of its specific state or position is called its:
explanation: The energy stored in an object because of its specific state or position is called its potential energy. (Page 24)

text: What is the formula for the potential energy (P.E.) of an object of mass 'm' at a height 'h' above the Earth's surface, where 'g' is acceleration due to gravity?
explanation: The amount of potential energy stored in an object of mass 'm' at height 'h' is P.E. = mgh. (Page 24)

text: The potential energy of an object is relative. This means:

options.text: It is always a positive value.
It depends on the reference level chosen for height.
It is the same for all observers.
It only depends on the mass of the object.

explanation: Potential energy is relative. For example, the height of a ball on a table will be different with respect to Ajay (standing on the ground) and Atul (if Atul is at a different reference level). So the potential energy with respect to them will be different. (Page 24)

text: What is the Law of Conservation of Energy?

options.text: Energy can be created but not destroyed.
Energy can be destroyed but not created.
Energy can neither be created nor destroyed, it can only be converted from one form to another.
The total amount of energy in the universe is constantly decreasing.

explanation: The Law of Conservation of Energy states that energy can neither be created nor destroyed. It can be converted from one form into another. Thus, the total amount of energy in the universe remains constant. (Page 25)

text: In an electric generator, which energy transformation takes place?
explanation: A generator transforms mechanical energy into electrical energy. (Page 25, diagram)

text: During the free fall of an object, what happens to its potential energy and kinetic energy?

options.text: Potential energy increases, kinetic energy decreases.
Potential energy decreases, kinetic energy increases.
Both potential and kinetic energy increase.
Both potential and kinetic energy decrease.

explanation: As an object falls freely, its height decreases, so its potential energy (mgh) decreases. Its velocity increases, so its kinetic energy (½ mv²) increases. The total mechanical energy (P.E. + K.E.) remains constant. (Page 26)

text: What is power defined as?

options.text: The total work done by an object.
The rate at which work is done.
The total energy possessed by an object.
The force applied per unit area.

explanation: Power is the rate at which work is done. If W amount of work is done in time t, then Power (P) = W/t. (Page 27)

text: The SI unit of power is:
explanation: In the SI system, the unit of work is J, so the unit of power is J/s. This is called watt (W). (Page 27)

text: One horsepower (hp) is equal to:
explanation: In the industrial sector, the unit used to measure power is called 'horse power'. 1 horse power = 746 watt. (Page 27)

text: The commercial unit of energy is:
explanation: The unit of energy for commercial use is kilowatt-hour (kWh). 1 kWh = 1 unit of electricity. (Page 27)

text: How many joules are there in 1 kilowatt-hour (kWh)?
A coolie lifts a luggage of 15 kg from the ground and puts it on his head 1.5 m above the ground. Calculate the work done by him on the luggage (assume g = 10 m/s²).
explanation: Force F = mg = 15 kg × 10 m/s² = 150 N. Displacement s = 1.5 m. Work W = Fs = 150 N × 1.5 m = 225 J. This is similar to the concept of calculating potential energy. (Page 22, 24)

text: An object of mass 10 kg is moving with a uniform velocity of 4 m/s. What is the kinetic energy possessed by the object?

Assertion (A): When a body falls freely towards the earth, then its total energy remains constant.
Reason (R): As a body falls freely, its potential energy is converted into kinetic energy.

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

explanation: During free fall, the total mechanical energy (sum of P.E. and K.E.) remains constant due to the law of conservation of energy. The potential energy decreases and converts into kinetic energy. (Page 26)

text:
Consider the following statements regarding work done:
1. Work done is positive if the angle between force and displacement is 0°.
2. Work done is zero if the angle between force and displacement is 90°.
3. Work done is negative if the angle between force and displacement is 180°.
How many of the above statements are true?
explanation: Statement 1: If θ=0°, W=Fs (positive). Statement 2: If θ=90°, W=0. Statement 3: If θ=180°, W=-Fs (negative). All statements are true. (Page 20)

text: A boy pushes a wall with a force of 100 N, but the wall does not move. What is the work done by the boy?
explanation: Work done (W) = Force (F) × displacement (s). Since the wall does not move, the displacement (s) is zero. Therefore, W = 100 N × 0 m = 0 J. (Page 18, 20)

text: Which scientist is credited with inventing the steam engine and has the unit of power named in his honour?
explanation: The steam engine was invented in 1781 by the Scottish scientist James Watt. The unit of power is called Watt in his honour. (Page 27)

text: If an electric iron of 1200 W is used for 30 minutes, how much electrical energy is consumed in kilowatt-hours?
explanation: Power P = 1200 W = 1.2 kW. Time t = 30 minutes = 0.5 hours. Energy E = P × t = 1.2 kW × 0.5 h = 0.6 kWh. (Page 27, similar to example on Page 39 of PDF)

text: The total mechanical energy of a freely falling body:

options.text: Is zero at the highest point.

explanation: For a freely falling body, the total mechanical energy (Potential Energy + Kinetic Energy) remains constant at all points during the fall, assuming no air resistance. (Page 26)

text: Which of these is NOT a unit of energy?
explanation: Joule and erg are units of energy (and work). Kilowatt-hour is also a unit of energy (commercial unit). Watt is the unit of power. (Page 20, 27)

text: A force of 20 N displaces an object by 5 m. If the work done is 50 J, what is the angle between the force and displacement?
explanation: W = Fs cos θ. So, 50 J = 20 N × 5 m × cos θ.  50 = 100 cos θ. cos θ = 50/100 = 0.5. The angle whose cosine is 0.5 is 60°. (Page 19)

text: The work done by a force can be zero even if there is a force and displacement. This occurs when:

options.text: Force and displacement are in the same direction.
Force and displacement are in opposite directions.
Force and displacement are perpendicular to each other.

explanation: Work done W = Fs cos θ. If the force and displacement are perpendicular, θ = 90°, and cos 90° = 0. Therefore, W = 0. (Page 20)

text:
Consider the following statements:
Statement 1: A fast cricket ball striking the stumps can do work.
Statement 2: The energy an object possesses due to its motion is potential energy.
Statement 3: Kinetic energy gained by an object is equal to the work done on it to achieve that motion from rest.
explanation: Statement 1 is true (it displaces the stumps). Statement 2 is false; energy due to motion is kinetic energy. Statement 3 is true (Kinetic energy = work done on the object). (Page 22)

text:
Assertion (A): The potential energy of a book on a table is zero.
Reason (R): Potential energy is relative and depends on the chosen reference level for height.

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

explanation: Assertion A is false because the potential energy of the book is zero only if the table surface is chosen as the reference level (h=0). Reason R is true; potential energy is relative. (Page 24)

text: Which of the following energy transformations occurs in a loudspeaker?
explanation: A loudspeaker converts electrical energy into sound energy. (Page 25, diagram)

text: At what point in its trajectory does a freely falling object (starting from rest at a height 'h') have maximum kinetic energy?

options.text: At the midpoint of its fall.
Kinetic energy is constant throughout the fall.

explanation: Just before hitting the ground, its height is minimum (almost zero), so P.E. is minimum. By conservation of energy, K.E. will be maximum at this point. (Page 26)

text: If a machine does 500 J of work in 10 seconds, what is its power?
explanation: Power P = Work (W) / Time (t) = 500 J / 10 s = 50 W. (Page 27)

text: The work done is said to be 1 erg when:

options.text: A force of 1 Newton displaces an object through 1 cm.
A force of 1 dyne displaces an object through 1 metre.
A force of 1 dyne displaces an object through 1 cm in the direction of the force.
A force of 1 Newton displaces an object through 1 metre.

explanation: If a force of 1 dyne displaces an object through 1 centimetre in the direction of the force, the amount of work done is 1 erg. (Page 20)

text: A stone of mass 250 g is falling from a height. Its kinetic energy is 0.5 J when its velocity is 2 m/s. What was the work done on the stone to achieve this velocity from rest?
explanation: The work done by a force to displace a stationary object through a distance s is the kinetic energy gained by the object. So, Work done = K.E. = 0.5 J. (Page 22, 23 example)

text: Consider the activity where Swaralee takes 20s to carry a bag weighing 20 kg to a height of 5m. If g = 9.8 m/s², the work done by Swaralee is 980 J. What is her power?
explanation: Power P = Work (W) / Time (t). Given W = 980 J and t = 20 s (not 40s as in the slightly different PDF example). P = 980 J / 20 s = 49 W. (Page 28, using data from question)

text: What type of work is done by the force of friction when an object slides on a rough surface?
explanation: The force of friction acts in the direction opposite to the displacement of the object. Therefore, the angle between the force of friction and displacement is 180°, and the work done is negative. (Page 20)

text: An object is lifted upwards. The work done by the gravitational force on the object is:

options.text: Equal to the work done by the lifting force

explanation: When an object is lifted upwards, its displacement is upwards. The gravitational force acts downwards. Since the force and displacement are in opposite directions, the work done by gravity is negative. (Page 20, 22 example)

text: A person holding a heavy suitcase and standing still at a bus stop does:
explanation: For work to be done in the physics sense, there must be displacement. Since the person is standing still, the displacement is zero, so the work done on the suitcase is zero. (Page 18, 20)

text: The potential energy of water stored in an overhead tank of a 10 m high building (mass of water = 500 kg, g = 9.8 m/s²) is:
explanation: P.E. = mgh = 500 kg × 9.8 m/s² × 10 m = 49000 J. (Page 24 example)

text: Which of the following statements about the law of conservation of energy is INCORRECT?

options.text: Energy can be converted from one form to another.
The total amount of energy in the universe remains constant.
Energy can be created if enough force is applied.

explanation: The law of conservation of energy states that energy can neither be created nor destroyed; it can only be converted from one form to another. So, statement (c) is incorrect. (Page 25)

text: When an arrow is released from a stretched bow, its ______ energy is converted into ______ energy.
explanation: A stretched bow stores potential energy (elastic potential energy). When the arrow is released, this potential energy is converted into the kinetic energy of the arrow. (Page 24 example)

text: The energy possessed by water stored at a height in a dam is primarily:
explanation: Water stored at a height possesses gravitational potential energy. (Page 24 example)

text: If the mass of an object is doubled, while its velocity remains constant, its kinetic energy will:
explanation: Kinetic energy K.E. = ½ mv². If mass 'm' is doubled to '2m', then new K.E. = ½ (2m)v² = 2 (½ mv²), so it is doubled. (Page 23)

text: A car of mass 1000 kg increases its speed from 10 m/s to 20 m/s. The work done by the engine is:
explanation: Work done = Change in K.E. = K.E_final - K.E_initial. K.E_initial = ½ × 1000 × (10)² = 50,000 J. K.E_final = ½ × 1000 × (20)² = 200,000 J. Work done = 200,000 J - 50,000 J = 150,000 J. (Page 22, concept of K.E)

text: Which of the following is an example of zero work done?

options.text: Catching a ball thrown by a friend.
Tying a stone to a string and swinging it in a horizontal circle at constant speed.
Stopping a moving car by applying brakes.

explanation: In uniform circular motion, the centripetal force is always perpendicular to the instantaneous displacement (velocity). Hence, the work done by the centripetal force is zero. (Page 20, 21)

text:
Consider the following statements regarding energy transformation:
1. A microphone converts sound energy into electrical energy.
2. A solar cell converts light energy into electrical energy.
3. An electric motor converts electrical energy into mechanical energy.
How many of the above statements are true?
explanation: All three statements correctly describe energy transformations: Microphone (Sound to Electrical), Solar cell (Light to Electrical), Electric motor (Electrical to Mechanical). (Page 25 diagram)

text:
Assertion (A): If an object is at rest, its kinetic energy is zero.
Reason (R): Kinetic energy depends on the mass and velocity of the object.

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

explanation: If an object is at rest, its velocity (v) is zero. Since K.E. = ½ mv², if v=0, then K.E.=0. This is because K.E. depends on mass and velocity. (Page 22, 23)

text: The definition of power involves which two physical quantities?
explanation: Power is defined as the rate of doing work, so it involves work and time (P = W/t). (Page 27)

text: An electric bulb is rated 100 W. What does this signify?

options.text: It consumes 100 J of energy per hour.
It consumes 100 J of energy per second.
It produces 100 J of light per second.
It has a resistance of 100 ohms.

explanation: Power rating in Watts (W) signifies the rate of energy consumption. 100 W means the bulb consumes 100 Joules of electrical energy per second. (Page 27)

text: Which of the following is an example of the transformation of chemical energy into heat and light energy?
explanation: Burning of wood is a chemical process (combustion) that releases stored chemical energy as heat and light energy. (Page 25, concept of energy transformation)

text: At the highest point of its trajectory, a vertically thrown ball (ignoring air resistance) has:

options.text: Maximum kinetic energy and minimum potential energy.
Minimum kinetic energy and maximum potential energy.
Maximum kinetic energy and maximum potential energy.
Minimum kinetic energy and minimum potential energy.

explanation: At the highest point, the ball momentarily stops (velocity=0), so its kinetic energy is minimum (zero). Its height is maximum, so its potential energy is maximum. (Page 26, concept of energy in free fall/projectile)

text: The CGS unit of work is:
explanation: In the CGS system, the unit of force is dyne and displacement is centimeter. Thus, the unit of work is dyne-centimetre, also called an erg. (Page 20)

text: If a force of 10 N acts on an object and the object is displaced by 2 m in the direction of the force, work done is:
explanation: Work = Force × Displacement = 10 N × 2 m = 20 J. (Page 18)

text: Pravin applies a force of 100 N on an object at an angle of 60° to the horizontal. The object gets displaced by 8 m in the horizontal direction. If cos 60° = 0.5, the work done is:
explanation: Work W = Fs cos θ = 100 N × 8 m × 0.5 = 400 J. (Page 22 example, Page 19 formula)

text: If a body of mass 'm' is lifted to a height 'h', the work done against gravity is stored as:
explanation: The work done to lift an object against gravity to a height 'h' is stored as its gravitational potential energy (mgh). (Page 24)

text: An engine does 1920 J of work in 2.4 minutes. Its power is:
explanation: Time t = 2.4 minutes = 2.4 × 60 seconds = 144 seconds. Power P = W/t = 1920 J / 144 s = 13.33 W. (Page 27)

text: Which of these represents potential energy?
explanation: A stretched rubber band stores elastic potential energy due to its deformed state. Moving car and flying bird have kinetic energy. Sound is a form of wave energy. (Page 24)

text:
Assertion (A): A person studying for an exam is doing a lot of work.
Reason (R): In physics, mental activity is considered as work only if it causes displacement.

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

explanation: Assertion A is false in the physics sense; mental activity without physical displacement is not considered work. Reason R correctly states the physics definition. (Page 18)

text:
Consider the following statements regarding energy units:
1. The SI unit of energy is Joule.
2. The CGS unit of energy is Erg.
3. 1 Kilowatt-hour is a unit of power.
How many of the above statements are true?
explanation: Statement 1 is true. Statement 2 is true. Statement 3 is false; Kilowatt-hour is a unit of energy (Power × Time). (Page 20, 27)

text: A solar water heater primarily converts:
explanation: A solar water heater absorbs solar (light) energy and converts it into heat energy to warm water. (Page 25, general concept of energy transformation)

text: An object of mass 2 kg is dropped from a height of 10 m. Its potential energy just before it is dropped is (g = 9.8 m/s²):
explanation: P.E. = mgh = 2 kg × 9.8 m/s² × 10 m = 196 J. (Page 24)

text: Work done by a force is a scalar quantity because:

options.text: It is the product of two vector quantities (force and displacement).
It only has magnitude and no specific direction.
It can be positive, negative, or zero.

explanation: Work done is the dot product of force and displacement (W = F ⋅ s = Fs cos θ), which results in a scalar quantity. Scalars have magnitude but no direction. Options a, c, and d describe properties or units but not why it's scalar. This is an 'out of PDF' conceptual question but based on the nature of work.

text: If the kinetic energy of a body is 200 J and its mass is 4 kg, its velocity is:
Power can also be expressed as:
explanation: Power P = W/t. Since W = Fs (for force and displacement in same direction), P = Fs/t. As s/t = v (velocity), P = Fv. This is an 'out of PDF' derivation but uses concepts from the chapter.

text: An electric motor lifts a 50 kg mass to a height of 10 m in 5 seconds. The power developed by the motor is (g = 10 m/s²):
explanation: Work done W = mgh = 50 kg × 10 m/s² × 10 m = 5000 J. Power P = W/t = 5000 J / 5 s = 1000 W. (Page 24, 27)

text: The primary function of the National Physical Laboratory, New Delhi, mentioned in the context of work and energy, is to:

options.text: Establish national standards of various physical quantities.

explanation: The National Physical Laboratory, New Delhi, has a main objective to establish national standards of various physical quantities. (Page 21)

text: A child pushes a toy car with a force parallel to the ground. If the car moves a certain distance, the work done by the child is:
explanation: Since the force applied by the child and the displacement of the car are in the same direction (parallel to the ground), the angle θ = 0°, and cos 0° = 1. Thus, work done is positive (W=Fs). (Page 19, 20)

text: If the net work done on an object moving with constant velocity is zero, this implies:

options.text: No forces are acting on the object.
The net force acting on the object is zero or forces are balanced.
The object must be in a vacuum.

explanation: If an object moves with constant velocity, its acceleration is zero. By Newton's second law, the net force on it is zero. If net force is zero, net work done (F_net * s) is also zero. This is an 'out of PDF' question integrating with Newton's laws, challenging understanding of net work.

text: The potential energy stored in a compressed spring is an example of:
explanation: A compressed spring stores energy due to its deformation (change in state). This is known as elastic potential energy. (Page 24 example)

text: What is the kinetic energy of a 0.5 kg ball thrown with a speed of 10 m/s?

Assertion (A): Power is a scalar quantity.
Reason (R): Power is defined as work done per unit time, and both work and time are scalar quantities.

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

explanation: Power is indeed a scalar quantity. Since work (a scalar) is divided by time (a scalar), the result (power) is also a scalar. (Page 27 concept).

text:
Consider the following statements about work and energy:
1. Work done against friction is always negative.
2. Potential energy can be converted into kinetic energy.
3. The unit 'horsepower' is used to measure energy.
How many of these statements are true?

options.text: None of the statements are true.

explanation: 1. Work done by friction is negative. Work done against friction (by an applied force overcoming friction) would be positive. So statement 1 as phrased can be tricky. If it means 'work done BY the force of friction', it's negative. If it means the work an external agent does to overcome friction, it's positive. Assuming it means 'work done BY the force of friction', it's negative. 2. True (e.g., free fall). 3. False, horsepower is a unit of power. Let's re-evaluate statement 1. 'Work done against friction' implies an external force doing positive work to move the object despite friction. The work done BY friction is negative. The question is slightly ambiguous. If we consider 'work done by the force of friction', it's negative. If we consider the work done by an external agent *against* friction, it's positive. Let's assume it means work done BY friction. Then statement 1 is false as it's negative. Let's assume standard phrasing 'Work done by friction is negative'. If the question is 'Work done BY friction...', then the work IS negative. 'Work done AGAINST friction' usually refers to the work done by the applied force that overcomes friction. The context suggests 'BY'. So statement 1 means work done by the force of friction is always negative; this is true. Statement 2 is true. Statement 3 is false. So, two statements are true. Let's re-read the PDF. Page 20 mentions 'negative work'. The force of friction opposes motion. So work done BY friction is negative. The question says 'Work done against friction'. This would typically be positive work done by an applied force. Let's assume the simplest interpretation: work done BY the force of friction. This work is negative. So statement 1 is: 'Work done BY friction is always negative' - TRUE. Statement 2: PE can be converted to KE - TRUE. Statement 3: Horsepower is unit of power, not energy - FALSE. Thus, 2 statements are true. (Page 20, 25, 27)

text: When a force F displaces an object by s, and the angle between F and s is θ, the work done is maximum when θ is:
explanation: Work W = Fs cos θ. Cos θ has a maximum value of 1 when θ = 0°. Thus, work done is maximum when force and displacement are in the same direction. (Page 19)

text: What happens to the potential energy of an object when its height above the ground is doubled?
explanation: Potential energy P.E. = mgh. If height 'h' is doubled to '2h', then new P.E. = mg(2h) = 2(mgh), so it gets doubled. (Page 24)

text: The work-energy theorem states that the net work done on an object is equal to:

options.text: The total energy of the object.
The power supplied to the object.

explanation: The work-energy theorem, a fundamental principle, states that the net work done on an object causes a change in its kinetic energy. (Implicit in K.E. = Work done on Page 22). This is a standard physics concept related to the chapter.

text: A hydroelectric power plant uses the ________ energy of water stored at a height to generate electricity.
explanation: Water stored at a height in a dam possesses potential energy. This potential energy is converted into kinetic energy as water falls, which then turns turbines to generate electricity. (Page 24, 25 transformation concept). This is an 'out of PDF' application.

text: If an object's speed is tripled, by what factor does its kinetic energy change?
explanation: K.E. = ½ mv². If speed v becomes 3v, then new K.E. = ½ m(3v)² = ½ m(9v²) = 9 (½ mv²). So, it changes by a factor of 9. (Page 23)

text: Two objects, A and B, have masses m and 2m respectively. If they have the same kinetic energy, what is the ratio of their velocities (v_A / v_B)?
explanation: K.E_A = ½ m v_A². K.E_B = ½ (2m) v_B². Given K.E_A = K.E_B. So, ½ m v_A² = ½ (2m) v_B². This simplifies to v_A² = 2 v_B². Therefore, v_A / v_B = √2 / 1 or √2 : 1. (Page 23). This is a challenging application.

text: One kilowatt is equal to:
explanation: The prefix 'kilo' means 1000. So, 1 kilowatt = 1000 watts. (Page 27, implicit)

text: A device converts 600 J of electrical energy into useful work in 1 minute. What is the useful power output?
explanation: Time t = 1 minute = 60 seconds. Work W = 600 J. Power P = W/t = 600 J / 60 s = 10 W. (Page 27)

text:
Assertion (A): The total energy of an isolated system always remains conserved.
Reason (R): Energy can be transformed from one form to another, but the total amount remains unchanged.

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

explanation: Assertion A is a statement of the law of conservation of energy for an isolated system. Reason R explains why this is so – due to transformation without creation or destruction. (Page 25)

text:
Consider the following scenarios:
1. A man pushing a stationary truck.
2. A satellite revolving around the Earth in a circular orbit.
3. A person climbing stairs.
In which of these scenarios is zero work done by the primary force involved in the action described?
explanation: 1. Stationary truck (s=0), so W=0. 2. Gravitational force on satellite is perpendicular to displacement, W=0. 3. Person climbing stairs does work against gravity. So, 1 and 2 involve zero work. (Page 18, 20, 21)

text: A freely falling object of mass 1 kg is at a height of 20 m. When it has fallen 10 m, its kinetic energy will be (g = 10 m/s²):
explanation: Initial P.E. = mgh_total = 1 * 10 * 20 = 200 J. When it has fallen 10 m, its height is 10 m. P.E. at this point = mgh_current = 1 * 10 * 10 = 100 J. By conservation of energy, K.E. = Initial Total Energy - Current P.E. = 200 J - 100 J = 100 J. (Page 26)

text: The term '1 unit' of electricity used for domestic purposes is equivalent to:
explanation: Electricity used for domestic purposes is measured in units of kilowatt-hour. 1 kWh = 1 unit. (Page 27)

text: When an object is thrown upwards, the work done by the force of gravity during its upward motion is:
explanation: During upward motion, displacement is upwards, while gravity acts downwards. Force and displacement are in opposite directions (θ=180°), so work done by gravity is negative. (Page 20)

text: Which of these energy transformations is LEAST likely to occur in a typical incandescent light bulb?
explanation: Incandescent bulbs convert electrical energy mainly into heat and some light. Light to chemical (like photosynthesis) is not its function. Electrical to potential energy is also not its primary transformation. Option c is least likely. This is an 'out of PDF' reasoning question based on common knowledge of bulb function and energy types. (Page 25, types of energy)

text: If two persons A and B do the same amount of work, but A takes half the time taken by B, then:

options.text: Power of A is half the power of B.
Power of A is double the power of B.
Power of A is equal to the power of B.
Power of A is four times the power of B.

explanation: Power P = W/t. Let W_A = W_B = W. Let t_B = T, so t_A = T/2. P_A = W / (T/2) = 2W/T. P_B = W/T. So, P_A = 2 P_B. Power of A is double the power of B. (Page 27)

text: The sum of kinetic and potential energy of an object is called its:
explanation: Mechanical energy is the sum of kinetic energy and potential energy. (Page 22, 26). This is a direct concept, although the explicit sum definition is more general than stated in the PDF text.

text: If a force F acts on a body and displaces it by a distance s in a direction perpendicular to the force, then the work done is:
explanation: If the direction of force is perpendicular to the direction of displacement, the angle θ = 90°. Since cos 90° = 0, the work done W = Fs cos 90° = 0. (Page 20)

text: A hydroelectric power station converts:

options.text: Kinetic energy of water into potential energy.
Potential energy of water into electrical energy.
Electrical energy into potential energy of water.
Heat energy of water into electrical energy.

explanation: In a hydroelectric power station, the potential energy of water stored at a height is first converted to kinetic energy (as it falls) and then this kinetic energy is used to turn turbines, which generate electrical energy. So, ultimately potential energy of water is converted into electrical energy. (Page 24, 25, 'out of PDF' application)

text:
Assertion (A): An object can have mechanical energy even if its momentum is zero.
Reason (R): Mechanical energy can exist as potential energy, which does not depend on motion.

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

explanation: An object at rest (zero momentum) at a certain height has potential energy, and thus mechanical energy. Potential energy (like gravitational PE = mgh) depends on position/state, not motion. (Page 22, 24, 'out of PDF' connection to momentum).

text: What is the primary reason for the flow of electric charge between two points in a conductor?

options.text: A difference in temperature between the two points.
A difference in electric potential between the two points.
A difference in the mass of electrons at the two points.
A difference in the color of the conductor at the two points.

explanation: Just like water flows from a higher level to a lower level, electric charge flows between two points due to a difference in electric potential, also known as potential difference. (Page 30)

text: In a conductor connected to a cell, electrons flow from:

options.text: The positive terminal to the negative terminal of the cell through the wire.
The center of the conductor outwards.

explanation: Electrons are negatively charged and flow from a point of lower potential (negative terminal of the cell) to a point of higher potential (positive terminal of the cell) through the conductor. (Page 31)

text: The SI unit of potential difference is:
explanation: The unit of potential difference in the SI system is Volt (V), named after the Italian scientist Alessandro Volta. (Page 31, 32)

text: What are free electrons in a metallic conductor?

options.text: Electrons tightly bound to the nucleus.
Outermost electrons that are very weakly bound to the nucleus and can move freely.
Protons that have gained an electron.
Neutrons that are free to move within the conductor.

explanation: Every atom of a metallic conductor has one or more outermost electrons which are very weakly bound to the nucleus. These are called free electrons and are carriers of negative charge. (Page 32)

text: Electric current (I) is defined as:

options.text: The total number of electrons in a conductor.
The charge (Q) passing through a conductor in unit time (t).
The potential difference across the ends of a conductor.
The resistance offered by the conductor to the flow of charge.

explanation: Quantitatively, current (I) is defined as the charge (Q) passing through a conductor in unit time (t). The formula is I = Q/t. (Page 33)

text: The SI unit of electric current is:
explanation: The SI unit of electric current is Ampere (A), named in recognition of the French mathematician and scientist, Ampere. (Page 33)

text: What is the conventional direction of electric current?

options.text: From the negative terminal to the positive terminal of a cell.
In the same direction as the flow of electrons.
From the positive terminal to the negative terminal of a cell.
Radially outwards from the source of charge.

explanation: Conventionally, the direction of current flow is taken to be opposite to the direction of flow of electrons, i.e., from the +ve end to the –ve end of a cell. (Page 33)

text: Ohm's law states that if the physical state of a conductor remains constant, the current (I) flowing through it is:

options.text: Inversely proportional to the potential difference (V) across its ends.
Directly proportional to the potential difference (V) across its ends.

explanation: Ohm's law states that if the physical state of a conductor remains constant, the current (I) flowing through it is directly proportional to the potential difference (V) between its two ends. (Page 34)

text: The SI unit of electrical resistance is:
explanation: The SI unit of resistance is called Ohm, indicated by the symbol Ω. It is named in honor of George Simon Ohm. (Page 34)

text: Resistivity (ρ) of a conductor depends on:

options.text: Its length and area of cross-section only.
The material it is made of only.
Its length, area of cross-section, and the material it is made of.
The current flowing through it and the potential difference across it.

explanation: At a given temperature, the resistance (R) of a conductor depends on its length (L), area of cross-section (A), and the material it is made of. Resistivity (ρ) is a specific property of the material itself. (Page 34)

text: What is the relationship between resistance (R), resistivity (ρ), length (L), and area of cross-section (A) of a conductor?
explanation: The resistance R of a conductor is given by the formula R = ρ (L/A), where ρ is the resistivity, L is the length, and A is the area of cross-section. (Page 35)

text: In an electric circuit, an ammeter is used to measure ________ and is always connected in ________.
explanation: An ammeter is used to measure current and is always connected in series in the circuit so that all the current passes through it. (Page 35, 36)

text: A voltmeter is used to measure potential difference and is always connected in _______ across the points between which the potential difference is to be measured.
explanation: A voltmeter is used to measure potential difference between two points and is always connected in parallel across those points. (Page 35, 36)

text: Which of the following materials has the lowest resistivity, making it a very good conductor?
explanation: Copper has a very low resistivity (1.7 × 10⁻⁸ Ωm), indicating it is an excellent conductor of electricity. Diamond has extremely high resistivity, and Nichrome has higher resistivity than copper. Glass is an insulator. (Page 35)

text: Substances which have very low resistance are called ________, while those with extremely high resistance are called ________.
explanation: Conductors are substances with very low resistance, allowing current to flow easily. Insulators (bad conductors) have extremely high resistance, preventing current flow. (Page 37)

text: When resistors are connected in series, the current flowing through each resistor is:
explanation: In a series arrangement, the same current flows through each resistor. (Page 39)

text: If three resistors R1, R2, and R3 are connected in series, their effective resistance (Rs) is given by:
explanation: The effective resistance of resistors connected in series is the sum of their individual resistances: Rs = R1 + R2 + R3. (Page 39)

text: One of the properties of a series combination of resistors is that the effective resistance is:

options.text: Smaller than each of the individual resistances.
Equal to the smallest individual resistance.
Larger than each of the individual resistances.
Equal to the average of the individual resistances.

explanation: In a series combination, the effective resistance is always larger than each of the individual resistances. (Page 40)

text: When resistors are connected in parallel, the potential difference across each resistor is:
explanation: In a parallel arrangement, the potential difference (voltage) across each resistor is the same. (Page 41, this is implied by the setup description and common knowledge for parallel circuits even if not explicitly stated as a property on page 40. Page 42 states this as property 3 for parallel connection).

text: If three resistors R1, R2, and R3 are connected in parallel, their effective resistance (Rp) is given by:
explanation: The inverse of the effective resistance of resistors connected in parallel is the sum of the inverses of their individual resistances: 1/Rp = 1/R1 + 1/R2 + 1/R3. (Page 41)

text: One of the properties of a parallel combination of resistors is that the effective resistance is:

options.text: Larger than each of the individual resistances.
Equal to the largest individual resistance.
Less than the least resistance of individual resistors.
Equal to the sum of the individual resistances.

explanation: In a parallel combination, the effective resistance of resistors connected in parallel is less than the least resistance of individual resistors. (Page 42, property 4)

text: In domestic electrical connections in India, the voltage difference between the live and neutral wires is about:
explanation: In India, the voltage difference between the live and neutral wires in domestic electrical connections is about 220V. (Page 43)
