explanation: Assertion (A) is true, immediate action is a key component of disaster management. Reason (R) is false; while damage assessment is part of it, disaster management also includes prevention, improving tolerance, relief, preparation, rescue, and rehabilitation. (Page 105)

text: If a victim has a fractured bone, the essential first aid is to:
explanation: If any bone is fractured, it is essential that the fractured part be immobilized. It can be done with the help of any available wooden rods/batons/rulers. (Page 105)

text: The carrying method suitable for an unconscious patient over a short distance is:
explanation: The Pulling or lifting method is used for carrying an unconscious patient, through a short distance. (Page 106)

text: Climate plays an important role in the weathering of rocks. This process primarily contributes to:
explanation: Various climatic factors bring about the weathering of rocks in the earth's crust. Climate also plays a very important role in the formation and enrichment of soil. (Page 97)

text: The first monsoon forecast in India, based on snowfall in the Himalayas, was made by:
explanation: After the famine of 1877, H. F. Blanford, the founder of IMD had made such a prediction for the first time taking the snowfall in the Himalayas as a parameter for this prediction. (Page 98)

text: The Indian Institute of Tropical Meteorology (IITM) is primarily involved in:

options.text: Daily weather map preparation and publication.
Developing new meteorological models and technology.

explanation: Presently, new models are being developed at the IITM. Work is in progress at two levels, namely, designing new models and developing new technology. The main focus is on development of the radar system and satellite technology. (Page 99)

text: Which of these is a characteristic of 'wet solid waste'?

options.text: It requires a very long period for degradation.
It mainly includes plastic and metal.
It is mainly of organic type and can be decomposed to get compost.

explanation: Biodegradable waste, also called ‘wet solid waste’ or ‘wet garbage’, is mainly of organic type. If it is carefully decomposed, we can get compost and fuel of good quality from it. (Page 101)

text: Consider the following: 1. Bandages, 2. Chemicals from industries, 3. Non-functional TV sets, 4. Fruit skins. Which of these are classified as Biomedical waste?
explanation: Biomedical waste includes bandages, dressings, gloves, needles, saline bottles, medicines, etc. Chemicals are industrial/hazardous, TV sets are electronic, fruit skins are domestic. (Page 101)

text: The first step in the ABC of first aid, 'Airway', involves ensuring:

options.text: The victim's respiratory passage is open.

explanation: Airway: If the victim has difficulty breathing, the head should be held in a backward sloping position or the chin should be raised so that the respiratory passage remains open. (Page 105)

text: Which method of transporting a patient is useful when support is needed for the part below the waist, and the patient can assist by holding their body upright?
explanation: Carrying on four-hand chair is useful when support is needed for the part below the waist. The image implies the patient can hold themselves somewhat. (Page 106)

text: Which of these factors is NOT directly studied as part of meteorology as defined in the text?

options.text: Geological movements of the earth related to climate

explanation: Meteorology includes the study of storms, clouds, rainfall, thunder, lightning, etc. and also inter-relationships with natural cycles and geological movements affecting climate. While oceanic currents and water cycle are related to climate (mentioned on page 97 as importance of weather), they are not explicitly listed as the direct *study objects* of meteorology on page 98 where it's defined. (Page 98, 97)

text: A key difference between biodegradable and non-biodegradable waste is:

options.text: Biodegradable waste is always dry, while non-biodegradable is always wet.
Biodegradable waste can be easily degraded by microbes, while non-biodegradable waste takes a very long time and special techniques.
Only non-biodegradable waste can be recycled.
Biodegradable waste mainly consists of metals and plastics.

explanation: Biodegradable waste is easily degraded by microbes. Non-biodegradable waste is not easily degraded because it requires a very long period of time and the use of various techniques. (Page 101)

text: The method of vermi-composting involves using what to decompose organic waste?

options.text: Specific bacteria in an anaerobic environment

explanation: Vermi-composting is a method of composting that utilizes earthworms to accelerate the decomposition of organic waste. This is general knowledge related to composting mentioned as a waste management method. (Page 102 - diagram mentions vermi-composting)

text: If a person has a sprained ankle, which part of the RICE remedy involves applying an ice-pack?
explanation: In the RICE remedy, 'Ice' involves applying an ice-pack to the injured part. (Page 106)

text: One of the harmful effects of improper solid waste management is the 'Production of toxic gases'. These gases primarily contribute to:
explanation: The production of toxic gases from improperly managed solid waste directly contributes to air pollution. (Page 102 - diagram)

text: The primary focus of the Indian Institute of Tropical Meteorology (IITM) regarding new models is on:

options.text: Development of radar systems and satellite technology.
International policy making for climate change.

explanation: The main focus of new model development at IITM is on the development of the radar system and satellite technology. (Page 99)

text: Which of these materials has the shortest degradation period according to the table on page 104?
explanation: Banana peelings have a degradation period of 3-4 weeks, which is shorter than cloth bags (1 month), rags (5 months), and woollen socks (1 year). (Page 104)

text:
Consider the following statements: 
1. Climate determines the diet and clothing of people in a region. 
2. Meteorology only studies past weather patterns. 
3. Solid waste is never a source of energy. 
How many of the above statements are true?
explanation: 1. True (Page 97). 2. False, meteorology also involves forecasting and current studies (Page 98). 3. False, solid waste can be a valuable source of energy if properly disposed of (Page 100). So, only 1 statement is true.

text: Assertion (A): It is difficult to make very large lenses for refracting telescopes. Reason (R): Large lenses are heavy and tend to get distorted.

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

explanation:
The question refers to content outside of Chapter 9. This question is 'out of PDF' but related to scientific instruments. Large lenses are indeed difficult to make, heavy, and prone to distortion, making this a general science fact relevant to instrumentation. Assuming this is knowledge that can be tested. (This info is actually from Chapter 18 page 210 of the provided PDF set, not Ch 9. I will make 'out of PDF' questions related to Env. Management.) 
Revising to be relevant: Assertion (A): Composting is an effective method for managing biodegradable waste. Reason (R): Biodegradable waste decomposes quickly into nutrient-rich soil conditioner when composted.

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

explanation: Composting is a well-known effective method for biodegradable waste, which turns into valuable soil conditioner (compost). This is 'out of PDF' in detail, but composting is mentioned on Page 102.

text: Improper handling of which type of waste poses a direct risk of spreading infectious diseases?
explanation: Biomedical waste, which includes items from clinics and hospitals like bandages, needles, body parts, can carry infectious agents and thus poses a risk of spreading diseases if not handled properly. Hazardous waste also lists infectious materials. (Page 101, 102)

text: Which of the following is NOT one of the 8 listed actions in Disaster Management?
explanation: The 8 actions listed for disaster management are: Prevention of losses and danger, Improving tolerance, Providing relief from disaster, Preparation to face the disaster, Immediate action, Assessment of damages, Arranging for rescue work and help, Rehabilitation and rebuilding. Assigning blame is not part of this structured approach. (Page 105)

text: The 'Human crutch method' for transporting a victim is specifically useful when:

options.text: The victim is a child or under-weight.
One of the victim's legs is injured.
A long distance needs to be covered.

explanation: Human crutch method: If one of the legs is injured, the victim should be supported with minimum load on the other leg. (Page 106)

text: Which of the following is a key characteristic that differentiates a statistical model from a dynamic mathematical model in climate prediction?

options.text: Statistical models use supercomputers, while dynamic models do not.
Statistical models rely on comparison with past parameters, while dynamic models use current physical interactions.
Statistical models focus on radar and satellite data, while dynamic models use ground observations.
Statistical models are always more accurate than dynamic models.

explanation: Statistical models compare current observations with earlier parameters. Dynamic (Mathematical) models take into account estimates of current weather related events and ongoing physical interactions. (Page 99)

text: An example of a proactive measure in disaster management would be:

options.text: Providing immediate medical aid after an earthquake.
Conducting regular earthquake drills in schools and offices.
Assessing the financial damage caused by a flood.
Rebuilding homes destroyed by a cyclone.

explanation: Proactive measures are taken *before* a disaster to prevent or mitigate its effects. Conducting drills falls under 'Preparation to face the disaster' and 'Improving tolerance'. The other options are reactive. This is an application of concepts from page 105.

text: The primary environmental concern with thermocol (styrofoam) is its:

options.text: Ability to absorb large amounts of water.

explanation: Thermocol/styrofoam cup is listed with an 'Infinite duration' for natural degradation, making it a persistent pollutant. (Page 104)

text: What is the main difference between the formation of soil via weathering and the enrichment of soil by microbes?

options.text: Weathering is a biological process, while microbial action is physical.
Weathering breaks down rocks to form soil particles, while microbes add organic matter and nutrients.
Weathering only occurs in cold climates, while microbial action only occurs in warm climates.
Both processes primarily involve the addition of water to the soil.

explanation: Weathering of rocks (physical/chemical breakdown) forms the mineral basis of soil. Microbes in the soil play an important role in the formation of organic materials, thus enriching it. (Page 97)

text: Assertion (A): Climate forecasting based solely on past data trends is always reliable. Reason (R): Climatic factors are independent and do not influence each other, simplifying predictions.

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
Both A and R are false.

explanation: Assertion (A) is false because climate is complex and past trends may not hold. Reason (R) is false; climatic factors are complex, interdependent, and influence each other, making predictions difficult. (Page 97)

text: Which of the following human activities would LEAST contribute to an increase in solid waste generation?

options.text: Purchasing single-use plastic water bottles daily.
Composting kitchen scraps and yard trimmings.
Frequent online shopping with excessive packaging.
Using disposable plates and cutlery for parties.

explanation: Composting kitchen scraps and yard trimmings is a form of waste reduction and recycling (creating compost), thus it would least contribute to the *increase* of problematic solid waste, unlike the other options which promote disposability and new waste. This question is 'out of PDF' but directly related to solid waste management principles. (Principles on Page 103)

text: A 'land-fill site' is primarily used for the management of which type of waste according to the diagram?
explanation: The diagram on page 102 shows 'Industrial solid waste management (land-fill method)' leading to 'Safe land-fill sites'. (Page 102)

text: The 'Elevate' component of the RICE remedy aims to:

options.text: Increase blood flow to the injured part.
Reduce swelling by helping fluid drain away from the injury.
Allow the victim to continue activity.

explanation: Elevate: The injured part should be kept in a raised / elevated position. This helps reduce swelling by promoting fluid drainage. This is a common understanding for 'elevate' in first aid. (Page 106)

text:
Consider the statements: 
Statement 1: Weather is a long-term average of atmospheric conditions. 
Statement 2: Meteorology helps in understanding and predicting weather patterns. 
Statement 3: Climate change can impact agricultural productivity.
explanation: Statement 1 is false (defines climate). Statement 2 is true (Page 98). Statement 3 is true (Page 97 mentions effect on agricultural production). Thus, statements 2 and 3 are true.

text: Which of these is an example of a natural disaster?
explanation: Natural disasters include thunderbolts (lightning), floods, fire (can be natural or man-made). Riots, chemical accidents, and bomb explosions are man-made. (Page 104)

text: The carrying method using a temporary stretcher made from bamboos and a blanket is suitable when:

options.text: The victim has a minor leg injury but can walk with support.
A conventional stretcher is not available in an emergency.
The victim is a small child.
The distance to be covered is very short and the victim is conscious.

explanation: Stretcher: In an emergency, if a conventional stretcher is not available, then a temporary stretcher can be made using bamboos, blanket, etc. (Page 106)

text: Which principle of solid waste management is best exemplified by choosing products with minimal packaging?
explanation: Choosing products with minimal packaging directly contributes to reducing the amount of waste generated. This is an 'out of PDF' application of the 'Reduce' principle. (Page 103)

text: If the Indian Meteorological Department issues a warning for a cyclone, this action falls under which aspect of disaster management?

options.text: Preparation to face the disaster (and Prevention of losses)
Immediate action in the disaster situation

explanation: Issuing a warning allows people and authorities to prepare and take measures to prevent losses, aligning with 'Preparation to face the disaster' and 'Prevention of losses and danger'. (Page 98, 105)

text: Assertion (A): All types of solid waste can be effectively managed through composting. Reason (R): Composting is a process that breaks down both organic and inorganic materials into useful soil conditioner.

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
Both A and R are false.

explanation: Assertion (A) is false; composting is primarily for organic (biodegradable) waste, not all types (e.g., plastics, metals). Reason (R) is false; composting breaks down organic materials, not inorganic materials like plastics or metals. (Page 101, 102)

text: Which of these is NOT a direct harmful effect of solid waste as listed in the diagram on page 102?
explanation: The diagram on page 102 lists spreading of diseases, soil pollution, water pollution, air pollution, degradation of natural beauty, production of toxic gases, and bad odour of waste. Increased rainfall is not listed as a direct effect. (Page 102)

text: The 'Breathing' step in the ABC of first aid involves:

options.text: Giving artificial ventilation if breathing has stopped.
Applying pressure to a bleeding wound.

explanation: Breathing: If breathing has stopped, the victim should be given artificial ventilation by mouth to mouth resuscitation. (Page 105)

text: What is the primary purpose of the 'Compression' step in the RICE first aid remedy?

options.text: To keep the injured area cold.
To prevent movement of the injured part.
To gently massage the injured part after ice application, potentially to reduce swelling or improve circulation.

explanation: Compression: After the ice-pack treatment, the injured part should be massaged gently. This describes the compression/massage aspect. (Page 106)

text: Which of the following practices best aligns with the 'Reduce' principle of waste management?

options.text: Using a reusable water bottle instead of buying bottled water.
Fixing a broken appliance instead of buying a new one.

explanation: Using a reusable water bottle directly reduces the generation of plastic bottle waste. Donating clothes is reuse, separating paper is recycle, fixing an appliance is reuse/reduce. This is an 'out of PDF' application. (Page 103)

text:
Consider the following: 
1. Weather forecasts are useful to farmers. 
2. All types of solid waste degrade at the same rate. 
3. First aid aims to start the process of rehabilitation. 
How many statements are true?
explanation: 1. True (Page 98). 2. False, degradation rates vary significantly (Page 104). 3. True (Page 105). So, 2 statements are true.

text: A key long-term impact of improper hazardous waste disposal is:

options.text: Contamination of soil and groundwater resources.
Increased aesthetic value of the area.

explanation: Hazardous waste, containing harmful chemicals and radioactive materials, can lead to long-term contamination of soil and groundwater if not disposed of properly. This is an 'out of PDF' critical thinking question based on the nature of hazardous waste. (Page 101)

text: The main goal of the 'Circulation' step in the ABC of first aid, especially involving CPR, is to:

options.text: Help bring the blood circulation back to normal.

explanation: Circulation: If the victim is unconscious... CPR... It helps to bring the circulation back to normal. (Page 105)

text: When is the 'Carrying piggy back' method most appropriate for transporting a victim?

options.text: When the victim has a spinal injury.
When the victim is unconscious and needs to be moved by one person.
When the victim has an injured leg but can support some weight.
When two rescuers are available for a conscious victim.

explanation: Carrying piggy back: Useful for carrying patients who are unconscious. The image shows one rescuer. (Page 106)

text: The process by which microbes break down organic waste into simpler substances is a fundamental part of:
explanation: Biodegradable waste is easily degraded by microbes. This is the basis of processes like composting. (Page 101)

text: A key advantage of the Holistic model for climate prediction is that it:

options.text: Is simpler to compute than mathematical models.
Considers the collective impact of parameters from various models that have the greatest effect.
Is independent of past climatic conditions.

explanation: In the Holistic model, predictions are based upon those parameters used in other models which have the greatest effect on the monsoon. Nowadays, predictions declared by IMD are the collective outcome of various models. (Page 99)

text: Which of these is a crucial aspect for successful composting of organic waste?

options.text: Presence of sufficient oxygen and moisture for microbial activity.
Mixing large amounts of plastic with the organic waste.
Keeping the waste in a sealed, airtight container.

explanation: Successful composting relies on aerobic microbial decomposition, which requires oxygen and adequate moisture. This is 'out of PDF' but core to understanding composting, which is mentioned. (Page 101, 102)

text: If a victim is suffering from heavy bleeding from a wound, the immediate first aid priority is to:

options.text: Elevate the wound above the heart.
Cover the wound with an antiseptic pad and apply pressure.
Clean the wound with cold water.

explanation: Bleeding: If the victim is injured and bleeding through the wound, then the wound should be covered with an antiseptic pad and pressure applied on it for 5 minutes with either thumb or palm. (Page 105)

text: Which of these is an example of 'Rethinking' in the context of environmental management, beyond just waste?

options.text: Using solar panels for electricity generation instead of coal.
Refusing a plastic straw at a restaurant.

explanation: 'Rethinking' our habits and activities can extend to energy consumption and choosing sustainable alternatives. While the text focuses on waste, this is a broader application of the 'Rethink' principle. This is an 'out of PDF' question. (Page 103)

text: The 'Cradle method' of carrying a victim is most similar in action to:

options.text: Two people carrying a log on their shoulders.
Carrying an infant in one's arms.
A person leaning on a crutch.

explanation: The cradle method, as depicted and described for children/under-weight victims, involves holding the victim in one's arms, similar to how one would cradle an infant. (Page 106)

text: Assertion (A): Climate refers to the atmospheric conditions over a very short period, like a day. Reason (R): Weather is the long-term average of daily atmospheric readings in a region.

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
Both A and R are false.

explanation: Both Assertion (A) and Reason (R) are false. Climate is the long-term average, and weather refers to short-term conditions. (Page 96)

text: Incineration is a waste management technique that primarily aims to:

options.text: Generate electricity through high-temperature burning of general waste.
Reduce the volume of waste, especially biomedical waste, through controlled burning.
Separate recyclable materials from mixed waste.

explanation: Incineration is listed under Biomedical waste management. Its primary purpose in this context is to destroy pathogens and reduce the volume of hazardous waste. (Page 102 - diagram)

text: A key component of 'Improving tolerance' in disaster management involves:

options.text: Increasing the strength of buildings to withstand disasters.
Providing financial aid after a disaster.
Ignoring potential risks to avoid panic.

explanation: 'Improving tolerance' refers to enhancing the capacity of communities and infrastructure to withstand the impact of disasters. This can include strengthening buildings, early warning systems, and community preparedness. This is an 'out of PDF' interpretation based on the listed principle. (Page 105)

text: What does ICT primarily include?

options.text: Only the services provided by communication devices
Communication devices, their use, and the services provided with their help
Only the internet and related technologies

explanation: The term Information Communication Technology (ICT) includes communication devices and the use of those devices as well as the services provided with their help. (Page 108)

text: The ENIAC computer, developed between 1946 and 1959, belongs to which generation of computers?
explanation: The computers used during the period between 1946 and 1959 are said to be ‘first generation computers.’ The ENIAC computer was made in this period. (Page 108)

text: Which component was primarily used in the construction of first-generation computers like ENIAC?
explanation: Valves were used in the construction of first-generation computers like ENIAC. These valves were large in size and consumed a lot of electricity. (Page 108)

text: Which of the following is NOT a primary unit of a computer's processor (CPU)?
explanation: The processor (CPU) consists of the Memory unit, Control unit, and ALU unit. The Input unit is separate and used for entering data into the computer. (Page 109)

text: What is the primary characteristic of RAM (Random Access Memory)?

options.text: Information stored can only be read, not changed.
It is a type of external memory.
It functions only as long as it is supplied with electricity (volatile).
It provides communication between the computer and the user.

explanation: RAM (Random Access Memory) is created from electronic components. Any electronic component can function only as long as it is supplied with electricity. This means it is volatile. (Page 109)

text: Which type of internal memory allows information to be read but not modified by the user?
explanation: ROM (Read Only Memory): The information stored here can only be read. We cannot make changes to the information originally stored here. (Page 109)

text: What is an Operating System (OS)?

options.text: A group of commands to be given to a computer.
A program that provides communication between the computer and the user.
The raw, unprocessed form of information.
The electronic and mechanical parts of a computer.

explanation: Operating system: This is a program which provides a means of communication between the computer and the person working on it. It is called the DOS (Disk Operating System). (Page 109)

text: Software in a computer system refers to:

options.text: All the electronic and mechanical parts used in computers.
The commands given to the computer, input information, and output results.
Only the physical components like monitor and keyboard.
The place for storing data obtained from the input.

explanation: Software: Software refers to the commands given to the computer, information supplied to it (input) and the results obtained from the computer after analysis (output). (Page 110)

text: When using Microsoft Word to type equations, which tab should you select to find the 'Equation' option?
explanation: To type equations in the text using Microsoft Word, select the ‘Equation’ option in the ‘Insert’ tab. (Page 110)

text: Which of the following is a precaution to take when entering data in a spreadsheet program like Microsoft Excel?

options.text: Enter all data in a single cell to save space.
Use many unnecessary spaces and special characters for better formatting.
Data should be kept in tabular form, and different types of data in different cells.
Always type formulae without the '=' sign.

explanation: As far as possible, the data should be kept in tabular form. Different types of data should be entered in different cells. Data should be entered neatly and in one ‘flow’. Unnecessary space and special characters should not be used. (Page 111)

text: What is the primary function of Microsoft PowerPoint?

options.text: To create and edit text documents.
To create and manage spreadsheets and graphs.
To create presentations with slides, animations, and designs.
To browse the internet and search for information.

explanation: Microsoft PowerPoint is used to create a presentation, which involves designing slides, adding information and pictures, and animating the slides for a slide show. (Page 112)

text: What is a PDF (Portable Document Format) file primarily used for?

options.text: Viewing, printing, and handling documents consistently across different platforms.

explanation: A PDF or Portable Document Format file can be used to view the file to print it or to handle files, ensuring the document looks the same regardless of the software or operating system. (Page 112)

text: Which of these is an example of using ICT for 'Prediction'?

options.text: Using Wikipedia to gather scientific information.
Using simulation to demonstrate the functioning of the nervous system.
Using meteorological data to forecast weather patterns.
Using email to communicate with colleagues.

explanation: Predictions can be made after compiling and processing information, for example, in meteorology. (Page 113)

text: Which of the following is NOT listed as an opportunity in the software field of computers?
explanation: Hardware assembly and testing is an opportunity in the hardware field, not the software field. Software field opportunities include application program development, software package development, OS & utility development, and special purpose scientific applications. (Page 113)

text: C-DAC, located in Pune, is known for developing which significant Indian technological achievement?

options.text: The first Indian mobile phone network.

explanation: C-DAC, the welknown Centre for Development of Advanced Computing, situated in Pune, developed the first Indian supercomputer, PARAM. (Page 113)

text: The supercomputer PARAM is capable of performing how many calculations per second?
explanation: The PARAM supercomputer can perform one billion calculations per second. (Page 113)

text: What is ISCII, which C-DAC participated in developing?

options.text: Indian Standard Code for Internet Interfacing
Indian Script Code for Information Interchange
International Software Code for Indian Industries
Indian Supercomputer Configuration for Integrated Informatics

explanation: C-DAC has also participated in developing the ISCII code (Indian Script Code for Information Interchange) for writing different language scripts. (Page 113)

text:
Assertion (A): First-generation computers frequently shut down.
Reason (R): They used valves which consumed a lot of electricity and generated significant heat.

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

explanation: First-generation computers like ENIAC used valves which were large, consumed a lot of electricity, generated heat, and caused computers to shut down many times. Thus, R correctly explains A. (Page 108)

text:
Consider the following statements about computer memory:
1. RAM is non-volatile memory.
2. ROM allows users to frequently change the stored information.
3. Internal memory is typically faster to access than external memory.
explanation: 1. RAM is volatile (functions only with electricity). So, statement 1 is false. 2. ROM is Read Only Memory; information cannot be changed. So, statement 2 is false. 3. Internal memory (like RAM, ROM) is generally faster than external memory (like hard drives). So, statement 3 is true. Therefore, only one statement is true. (Page 109)

text: What does 'data' represent in the context of computing?

options.text: The final, processed output from a computer.
A group of commands given to the computer.
Information in its raw, unprocessed form.
The physical components of the computer system.

explanation: Data and information: Data is information in its raw (unprocessed) form. (Page 109)

text: Which of these is an example of computer hardware?
explanation: Hardware consists of all the electronic and mechanical parts used in computers. The CPU is a key electronic part. Microsoft Word, the OS, and a PDF file are examples of software. (Page 110)

text: When creating a graph in Microsoft Excel, after typing the information, what is the next immediate step mentioned?

options.text: Select the information and click on the required graph in the 'Insert' tab.
Format the cells containing the data.

explanation: After you have finished typing, ‘Select’ the information and click on the required graph in the ‘Insert’ tab. (Page 111)

text: Which symbol must typically be typed first when entering a formula in a spreadsheet cell?
explanation: While using a formula, the ‘=’ sign should be typed first. (Page 111)

text: Internet Explorer is described as a type of:
explanation: Internet Explorer: This is a kind of Search Engine. It helps to find the information we want from all the information available on the internet. (Page 112). Note: While IE is a browser, the text describes its function in the context of finding information, similar to a search engine's role within the browser.

text: Which ICT tool is specifically mentioned for demonstrating scientific concepts easily and effectively using simulation and animation?
explanation: Some experiments and concepts in science can be demonstrated easily and effectively by using simulation and animation e.g. functioning of the nervous system. This falls under 'Demonstration' as a use of ICT. (Page 113)

text: Which of the following is a common method for collecting scientific information using ICT?

options.text: Internet, emails, newsgroups, blogs, Wikipedia, video conferencing

explanation: Collecting scientific information can be done using Internet, emails, newsgroups, blogs, chat rooms, Wikipedia, video conferencing, etc. (Page 113)

text: The term 'PARAM' associated with India's supercomputer means:
explanation: PARAM means the supreme. This computer can perform one billion calculations per second. (Page 113)

text:
Assertion (A): A computer cannot function without an operating system.
Reason (R): The operating system provides a means of communication between the computer and the person working on it.

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

explanation: We cannot use a computer without its operating system. The operating system is a program which provides a means of communication between the computer and the person working on it. Both statements are true and R correctly explains A. (Page 109)

text:
Consider the following statements regarding opportunities in the computer field:
1. Hardware field opportunities include software package development.
2. Training new entrants is a vast field requiring competent teachers.
3. Marketing requires sales personnel skilled in computer workings.
explanation: 1. Software package development is in the software field, not hardware. So statement 1 is false. 2. Training new entrants is important and needs competent teachers. So statement 2 is true. 3. Marketing needs good sales personnel experienced in computer workings. So statement 3 is true. Therefore, only 2 statements are true. (Page 113)

text: Which of the following is an example of a utility program, a type of software?
explanation: Utility development is mentioned as an opportunity in the software field. Antivirus programs are a common example of utility software that helps maintain and protect the computer system. Application programs (word processor), browsers, and games are other types of software. (Page 113 for context on software fields, specific example is out of PDF but related)

text: The 'explosion of information' is primarily attributed to:

options.text: The advances in science and technology.
The decline in the use of communication devices.
The stagnation in research and development.

explanation: The store of information generated due to the advances in science and technology is increasing at a tremendous rate. This is referred to as the explosion in information. (Page 108)

text: If a computer from 1950 (first generation) were compared to a modern (fifth generation) computer, a key difference would be:

options.text: The 1950 computer would be much smaller and more power-efficient.
The 1950 computer would use microprocessors instead of valves.
The 1950 computer would be larger, consume more electricity, and generate more heat.
The 1950 computer would have a more advanced operating system.

explanation: First generation computers used valves, were large, consumed a lot of electricity, and generated heat. Modern computers are significantly more advanced, smaller, and power-efficient. (Page 108)

text: Which unit of the computer is primarily responsible for performing arithmetic and logical operations?
explanation: The ALU (Arithmetic Logic Unit) unit within the processor is responsible for performing arithmetic calculations and logical comparisons. (Page 109)

text: What is a computer 'program' defined as in the context of this chapter?

options.text: The physical casing of the computer.
A group of commands to be given to a computer.
The screen or monitor used for output.

explanation: Program: A program is a group of commands to be given to a computer. (Page 109)

text: To make typed material attractive in Microsoft Word, options like font size and bold are typically found in which tab?
explanation: Use the language, font size, bold, etc. options in the Home tab to make the typed material attractive in Microsoft Word. (Page 110)

text: The 'smart tag' in Microsoft Excel is mentioned as useful when:

options.text: Dragging and filling data to fill it in any manner as required.

explanation: Many times we ‘drag and fill’ data. At such times, the ‘smart tag’ can be used after ‘drag data’ to fill any data in any manner as required. (Page 111)

text: Which tab in Microsoft PowerPoint is used to animate a slide and make a slide show?
explanation: Use the ‘Animation’ tab to animate the slide and make a slide show in Microsoft PowerPoint. (Page 112)

text: Which of these is an example of using ICT for demonstration?

options.text: Video conferencing with a remote team.
Using software to simulate the functioning of the nervous system.
Forecasting the weather using meteorological data.
Searching for research papers on the internet.

explanation: Some experiments and concepts in science can be demonstrated easily and effectively by using simulation and animation e.g. functioning of the nervous system. (Page 113)

text: Which of these is NOT a primary job opportunity area in the hardware field of computers?
explanation: Application program development falls under the software field. Opportunities in the hardware field include hardware designing, production, assembly, testing, maintenance, servicing, and repairs. (Page 113)

text: C-DAC is primarily involved in:

options.text: Conducting research in the field of computers and developing advanced computing.
Training personnel for marketing computer accessories.

explanation: C-DAC, the welknown Centre for Development of Advanced Computing, situated in Pune, is the leading institute in India which conducts research in the field of computers. (Page 113)

text: What is the significance of the increasing speed of computers in the modern age?

options.text: It has made computers more expensive and less accessible.
It has limited the fields where computers can be used.
It has enabled the entry of computers into all fields of work.
It has reduced the need for software development.

explanation: The entry of computers in all fields in this age of technology has been possible only due to the increased speed of computers. (Page 109)

text:
Assertion (A): ROM is used for storing frequently changing user data.
Reason (R): Information in ROM can be easily modified and rewritten by the user.

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
Both A and R are false.

explanation: ROM (Read Only Memory) stores information that can only be read and cannot be easily changed by the user. It's not typically used for frequently changing user data. Therefore, both A and R are false. (Page 109)

text:
How many of the following are examples of computer output devices?
1. Keyboard
2. Monitor
3. Printer
4. Mouse
explanation: A screen/monitor or printer is used as an output unit. Keyboard and mouse are input devices. So, statements 2 and 3 are true. (Page 109)

text: Which category of software would a meteorological forecasting system fall under?
explanation: Meteorological forecasting is a specialized scientific task. Such systems are examples of special purpose scientific applications, a category within the software field. (Page 113)

text: The concept of different 'generations' of computers primarily refers to changes in:

options.text: The physical size of the monitor.
The underlying technology used for processing and memory (e.g., valves, transistors, ICs).
The color of the computer casing.
The number of software applications pre-installed.

explanation: The progression through computer generations is marked by significant changes in the core technology, such as from valves (1st gen) to transistors (2nd gen), integrated circuits (3rd gen), and microprocessors (4th gen onwards). (Page 108 implicitly, general computer knowledge relevant to the chapter's context)

text: What type of ICT device is a 'television set' primarily considered in the provided table context?

options.text: An input device for data entry.
A processing device for complex calculations.
A device for receiving and displaying broadcast information (audio-visual).
A storage device for large amounts of data.

explanation: A television set is listed as an ICT device. Its primary function is to receive broadcast signals (or other video inputs) and display information in an audio-visual format. (Page 108)

text: DOS (Disk Operating System) is an example of:
explanation: The operating system is a program which provides a means of communication between the computer and the person working on it. It is called the DOS (Disk Operating System). (Page 109)

text: Using ICT to create a simulation of a complex scientific experiment for educational purposes is an example of its use in:
explanation: Some experiments and concepts in science can be demonstrated easily and effectively by using simulation and animation. This falls under the category of 'Demonstration'. (Page 113)

text: The job opportunity of 'hardware maintenance, servicing and repairs' falls under which field in the computer industry?
explanation: Job opportunities in hardware designing, hardware production, hardware assembly and testing, hardware maintenance, servicing and repairs, etc., are listed under the Hardware field. (Page 113)

text: The PARAM supercomputer is NOT typically used for which of the following applications?
explanation: PARAM is used in fields like space research, movements in the interior of the earth, research in oil deposits, medicine, meteorology, engineering, military etc. Personal document creation is typically done on personal computers. (Page 113)

text: If you need to create a new blank document in Microsoft Word, which tab would you typically access first?
explanation: To create a new document in Microsoft Word, you select the ‘New’ option in the ‘File’ tab, and then select the ‘Blank document’ option. (Page 110)

text:
Assertion (A): Software refers to the physical components of a computer that you can touch.
Reason (R): Hardware includes programs and data that instruct the computer.

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
Both A and R are false.

explanation: Software refers to commands and programs, not physical components. Hardware refers to the physical electronic and mechanical parts. Thus, both Assertion (A) and Reason (R) are false as they have interchanged definitions. (Page 110)

text:
How many of the following are listed as precautions for data entry in MS Excel?
1. Data should be kept in tabular form.
2. While using a formula, the ‘+’ sign should be typed first.
3. Unnecessary space and special characters should be used extensively for clarity.
explanation: 1. Data in tabular form is a precaution. 2. The '=' sign should be typed first for a formula, not '+'. 3. Unnecessary space and special characters should NOT be used. So only statement 1 is a correct precaution. (Page 111)

text: Which of the following is a defining characteristic of 'Big Data' that differentiates it from traditional data?

options.text: High volume, high velocity, and high variety.
Data that can only be processed by supercomputers.

explanation: Big Data is characterized by the 'three Vs': Volume (large amounts), Velocity (fast rate of generation/processing), and Variety (different types of data - structured, unstructured, semi-structured). This is an out-of-PDF concept related to the 'explosion of information' theme. (Page 108 for theme context)

text: Which of the following best describes 'cloud computing'?

options.text: Storing all data on a personal physical hard drive.
Accessing computing resources (like storage, servers, software) over the internet on demand.
Developing software exclusively for mobile devices.

explanation: Cloud computing involves delivering various computing services—including servers, storage, databases, networking, software, analytics, and intelligence—over the Internet (“the cloud”) to offer faster innovation, flexible resources, and economies of scale. This is an out-of-PDF concept relevant to modern ICT.

text: The telephone is an example of an ICT device primarily used for:
explanation: For example, the telephone is used for sharing information by conversing with someone. (Page 108)

text: A computer's Memory unit is primarily used for:

options.text: Storing data obtained from input and generated solutions.
Displaying the final output to the user.

explanation: Memory: Memory is the place for storing data obtained from the input and also the generated solution or answer by the computer. (Page 109)

text: The 'Design' tab in Microsoft PowerPoint is primarily used for:

options.text: Changing the visual appearance and layout of your slide.

explanation: Use the ‘Design’ tab to design your slide in Microsoft PowerPoint. This involves changing themes, colors, backgrounds, etc. (Page 112)

text: Which of these tasks is NOT a primary job of a marketing professional in the computer field?

options.text: Having experience in the working of computers.
Developing operating systems and utility programs.

explanation: Developing operating systems and utility programs is a task for the software field. Marketing professionals need to sell products and be knowledgeable about them and marketing strategies. (Page 113)

text: The senior scientist associated with the guidance for making the PARAM supercomputer was:
explanation: Valuable guidance for making this computer (the Param computer) was received from the senior scientist Vijay Bhatkar. (Page 113)

text: The primary disadvantage of first-generation computers mentioned was their:

options.text: Tendency to shut down due to heat and high electricity consumption.

explanation: First-generation computers consumed a lot of electricity, which generated heat, and computers would shut down many times. (Page 108)

text:
Assertion (A): A keyboard is generally used as an output unit.
Reason (R): The result or solution is eventually sent to the output unit.

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

explanation: Assertion (A) is false; a keyboard is an input unit. Reason (R) is true; the output unit receives the result/solution. (Page 109)

text:
Consider the following regarding computer components:
1. Hardware consists of commands given to the computer.
2. Software includes electronic and mechanical parts.
3. An operating system is a type of hardware.
explanation: 1. Hardware consists of electronic and mechanical parts, not commands. 2. Software refers to commands and programs, not physical parts. 3. An operating system is a type of software. Therefore, all 3 statements are false. (Page 109, 110)

text: The 'Internet of Things' (IoT) refers to:

options.text: A new version of the Internet Explorer browser.

A network of physical devices, vehicles, home appliances and other items embedded with electronics, software, sensors, actuators, and connectivity which enables these objects to connect and exchange data.
A global network of supercomputers like PARAM.
A specialized software for managing large databases.

explanation: The Internet of Things (IoT) describes the network of physical objects—“things”—that are embedded with sensors, software, and other technologies for the purpose of connecting and exchanging data with other devices and systems over the Internet. This is an out-of-PDF concept, expanding on ICT.

text: Which of the following is an ethical concern related to the widespread use of ICT?
explanation: While ICT offers many benefits, ethical concerns such as data privacy violations, security risks, spread of misinformation, and digital divide are significant. This is an out-of-PDF question, encouraging broader thinking about ICT's impact.

text: A key characteristic of ROM (Read Only Memory) is that it is typically:

options.text: Volatile and used for temporary storage.
Non-volatile and stores firmware or boot instructions.
Easily erasable and rewritable by the user.
A form of external storage like a USB drive.

explanation: ROM is non-volatile, meaning it retains data even when power is off. It often stores firmware or the basic input/output system (BIOS) necessary for booting the computer. The text states its information can only be read, not easily changed. (Page 109, extended by general knowledge related to ROM's purpose)

text: The Control Unit within a CPU is responsible for:

options.text: Directing and coordinating most of the operations within the computer.

explanation: The Control Unit (CU) is a component of a computer's central processing unit (CPU) that directs the operation of the processor. It tells the computer's memory, arithmetic logic unit and input and output devices how to respond to the instructions that have been sent to the processor. (Page 109 mentions Control Unit as part of processor, further detail is general knowledge)

text: Open-source software is characterized by:

options.text: Having its source code available for modification and distribution.
Only being usable on specific proprietary hardware.
Being developed and maintained by a single company.

explanation: Open-source software is software with source code that anyone can inspect, modify, and enhance. This is an out-of-PDF concept relevant to understanding different types of software in ICT.

text: The 'digital divide' refers to:

options.text: The gap between different generations of computer hardware.
The difference in processing speeds of various CPUs.
The gap between those who have access to modern information and communication technology and those who do not.
The division of software into application and system software.

explanation: The digital divide refers to the unequal access to digital technology, including smartphones, tablets, laptops, and the internet. This is an important societal issue related to ICT. (Out of PDF, but relevant socio-technical aspect of ICT)

text: What is a key benefit of using Portable Document Format (PDF) files?

options.text: They are easily editable by anyone without special software.
They maintain the original formatting of a document across different devices and operating systems.
They are primarily used for creating interactive animations.
They occupy very little storage space compared to other document formats.

explanation: PDF files are designed to present documents consistently, regardless of software, hardware, or operating systems. This means the layout, fonts, and images will look the same as intended by the creator. (Page 112 for mention of PDF, benefit is general knowledge)

text: Which component of a computer is responsible for the initial boot-up sequence and loading the operating system?
explanation: ROM often contains the BIOS (Basic Input/Output System) or firmware, which includes instructions to start the computer, check hardware, and load the operating system from a storage device. (Page 109 context of ROM, boot-up is general knowledge)

text:
Assertion (A): Supercomputers like PARAM are primarily designed for everyday office tasks like word processing.
Reason (R): Supercomputers possess immense processing power suitable for complex scientific and engineering calculations.

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

explanation: Assertion (A) is false; supercomputers are not for everyday office tasks. Reason (R) is true; they are used for complex calculations in fields like space research, meteorology, etc. (Page 113)

text:
How many of the following are examples of using ICT for communication?
1. Sending an email.
2. Participating in a video conference.
3. Creating a spreadsheet to track expenses.
4. Using a chat room.
explanation: Email, video conferencing, and chat rooms are all methods of communication using ICT. Creating a spreadsheet is primarily for data organization and calculation, not direct communication in this context. So, statements 1, 2, and 4 are true. (Page 113 lists these under collecting scientific information, but they are inherently communication tools)

text: The term 'firmware' often refers to software that is:

options.text: Permanently programmed into a hardware device, typically in ROM.
Used for creating graphical user interfaces.
A type of application software for specific tasks.

explanation: Firmware is a specific class of computer software that provides the low-level control for a device's specific hardware. It is often stored in ROM or flash memory. (Related to ROM discussion on Page 109, firmware is a more specific out-of-PDF term)

text: A key challenge in managing the 'explosion of information' is:

options.text: The lack of available storage devices.
The difficulty in accessing any information at all.
Filtering relevant and credible information from the vast amounts available.
The slow speed of modern internet connections.

explanation: With the 'explosion of information', a significant challenge is not just accessing it, but sifting through it to find what is relevant, accurate, and trustworthy. (Inferred from Page 108's statement about knowledge becoming outdated if we ignore the explosion)

text: A 'blog' is a type of ICT tool primarily used for:

options.text: Real-time text-based conversations between multiple users.
Publishing articles, posts, or diary-style entries online, often with reader comments.
Securely storing and sharing large files.

explanation: Blogs are online journals or informational websites displaying information in reverse chronological order, with the latest posts appearing first. They are a platform for writers or groups of writers to share their views on an individual subject. (Page 113 lists blogs as a way of collecting scientific information)

text: If a computer seems to be running very slowly, which of the following hardware components is LEAST LIKELY to be the direct cause if it's not faulty?

options.text: A slow or fragmented hard disk drive

explanation: Insufficient RAM, a slow hard drive, or an old CPU can all contribute to a computer running slowly. The casing itself, unless it's causing overheating due to poor ventilation, doesn't directly impact performance. (Understanding of hardware from Page 110 and general computer knowledge)

text:
Assertion (A): C-DAC is located in Bengaluru.
Reason (R): C-DAC developed the ISCII code for Indian language scripts.

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

explanation: Assertion (A) is false; C-DAC is situated in Pune. Reason (R) is true; C-DAC participated in developing the ISCII code. (Page 113)

text:
Consider these ICT applications:
1. Using a GPS device for navigation.
2. Playing a video game on a console.
3. A doctor using software to analyze medical images.

options.text: Only 1 and 2 are examples of ICT application.
Only 2 and 3 are examples of ICT application.
Only 1 and 3 are examples of ICT application.
All 1, 2, and 3 are examples of ICT application.

explanation: All three are examples of how Information and Communication Technology is applied in various fields: navigation (GPS), entertainment (video games), and healthcare (medical image analysis). The chapter provides a broad definition of ICT. (Page 108 for broad definition, examples are out-of-PDF but direct applications)

text: The 'motherboard' of a computer is a crucial piece of hardware that:

options.text: Primarily stores the operating system and user files.
Serves as the main printed circuit board connecting essential components like CPU, RAM, and expansion slots.
Is solely responsible for displaying images on the monitor.
Is an external device used for data input.

explanation: The motherboard is the main circuit board of a computer. It holds and allows communication between many of ઉthe crucial electronic components of a system, such as the central processing unit (CPU) and memory, and provides connectors for other peripherals. (Out-of-PDF, but fundamental hardware knowledge linked to Page 110)

text: If a computer's hard drive fails, what is the most likely immediate consequence?

options.text: The monitor will stop displaying images.
The computer will be unable to access the operating system and stored user files.
The CPU will overheat and shut down.
The keyboard and mouse will become unresponsive.

explanation: The hard drive is typically where the operating system and user data are stored. If it fails, the computer usually cannot boot up or access this information. (Inferred from understanding of OS and data storage, Page 109, and general computer knowledge)

text: Artificial Intelligence (AI) in ICT refers to:

options.text: The physical intelligence of computer hardware components.
The simulation of human intelligence processes by machines, especially computer systems.
A type of advanced operating system.
A new standard for internet connectivity.

explanation: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is a branch of computer science concerned with building smart machines capable of performing tasks that typically require human intelligence. (Out-of-PDF, a significant area of modern ICT progress)

text: Which of the following best describes the function of a 'compiler' or 'interpreter' in programming?

options.text: To design the graphical user interface of an application.
To translate human-readable programming code into machine-executable code.
To manage the computer's memory allocation.
To provide network connectivity for the computer.

explanation: Compilers and interpreters are programs that convert source code written in a high-level programming language into machine code that the computer's processor can execute. (Related to 'Program' definition on Page 109, this is a deeper out-of-PDF concept)

text:
Assertion (A): Wikipedia is a reliable source for primary scientific research data.
Reason (R): Wikipedia allows collaborative editing by users, which can sometimes lead to inaccuracies or biases.

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

explanation: Assertion (A) is false; while Wikipedia (mentioned on Page 113) can be a good starting point, it's generally not considered a source for primary scientific research data due to its open editing model. Reason (R) is true; its collaborative nature can lead to inaccuracies. Thus, R explains why A is generally false.

text:
How many of the following are types of operating systems?
1. Microsoft Word
2. Android
3. iOS
4. PARAM
explanation: Microsoft Word is application software. Android and iOS are mobile operating systems. PARAM is a supercomputer. So, only Android and iOS are operating systems from the list. (Page 109 mentions OS and DOS, Android/iOS are common examples - out of PDF)

text: Which of the following is an example of a 'graphical user interface' (GUI)?

options.text: Typing commands into a DOS prompt.
The visual system of icons, windows, and menus used in modern operating systems like Windows or macOS.
The internal circuitry of a CPU.
A programming language like Python or Java.

explanation: A GUI allows users to interact with electronic devices through graphical icons and visual indicators, as opposed to text-based command lines like DOS. (Related to OS on Page 109, GUI is an out-of-PDF concept detailing the user interface)

text: The use of ICT in meteorology primarily helps in:

options.text: Compiling and processing data for weather prediction.

explanation: ICT is used in meteorology for compiling and processing information to make predictions. (Page 113)

text: A 'search algorithm' used by search engines like Google or Bing is a type of:

options.text: Hardware component for faster internet access.
Software program designed to find information on the World Wide Web based on user queries.

explanation: Search algorithms are complex software programs that search engines use to find and rank web pages relevant to a user's search query. (Internet Explorer mentioned as search engine on Page 112, algorithm is an out-of-PDF detail)

text: Cybersecurity is a field of ICT primarily concerned with:

options.text: Protecting computer systems, networks, and data from theft, damage, or unauthorized access.
Creating new software applications for entertainment.

explanation: Cybersecurity focuses on the protection of internet-connected systems, including hardware, software, and data, from cyber threats. (Out-of-PDF, an essential aspect of modern ICT)

text: The concept of 'information overload' is a direct consequence of:

options.text: The limited storage capacity of modern computers.
The 'explosion of information' made accessible by ICT.
The slow processing speeds of first-generation computers.
The lack of effective search engines.

explanation: Information overload refers to the difficulty a person can have understanding an issue and making decisions that can be caused by the presence of too much information. This is directly related to the 'explosion of information' mentioned on Page 108.

text: Which of the following best represents the hierarchy from data to knowledge?
explanation: Data is raw facts. When data is processed, organized, structured, or presented in a given context so as to make it useful, it is called information. Knowledge is the understanding and application of that information. (Page 109 defines data as raw information, the hierarchy is a standard DIKW pyramid concept)

text: A spreadsheet software like MS Excel is most suitable for which of these tasks?

options.text: Creating a photo slideshow with music.
Organizing numerical data, performing calculations, and creating charts.
Designing a 3D model of a building.

explanation: MS Excel is used to draw graphs based on numerical information, implying its use for organizing data and performing calculations. (Page 111)

text: What is a primary benefit of video conferencing as an ICT tool?

options.text: It enables face-to-face communication and collaboration among geographically dispersed individuals.
It is primarily used for broadcasting pre-recorded lectures.

explanation: Video conferencing facilitates real-time, visual and audio communication between people in different locations, enabling meetings and collaborations without physical presence. (Page 113 lists it as a tool for collecting scientific information, its benefit is an extension)

text: The training field in the computer industry is crucial because:

options.text: It focuses on selling computer hardware.
It is responsible for developing new software applications.
It ensures that new entrants are competent and skilled for various jobs in the computer field.
It primarily deals with hardware maintenance and repair.

explanation: The training of new entrants for various jobs is a vast field. It is very important to have dedicated teachers who are competent in the field of computers. (Page 113)

text:
Assertion (A): The PARAM supercomputer was developed by an international consortium.
Reason (R): Vijay Bhatkar played a key role in guiding its development.

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

explanation: Assertion (A) is false; PARAM was the first Indian supercomputer, developed by C-DAC. Reason (R) is true; Vijay Bhatkar provided valuable guidance. (Page 113)

text:
How many of the following are typically considered part of computer 'software'?
1. CPU
2. Operating System
3. Microsoft Excel
4. Monitor
explanation: CPU and Monitor are hardware. Operating System and Microsoft Excel are types of software. So, statements 2 and 3 are true. (Page 110)

text: The term 'E-commerce' refers to:

options.text: The study of electronic components in computers.
The buying and selling of goods and services over the internet.
The process of developing computer hardware.

explanation: E-commerce (electronic commerce) is the activity of electronically buying or selling of products on online services or over the Internet. (Out-of-PDF, but a very common application of ICT)

text: What is the primary purpose of an 'Uninterruptible Power Supply' (UPS) for a computer?

options.text: To increase the processing speed of the CPU.
To provide backup power in case of an electricity outage, allowing for safe shutdown.
To connect the computer to the internet.
To store large amounts of user data externally.

explanation: A UPS provides emergency power to a load when the input power source or mains power fails. It allows for orderly shutdown of the computer and connected equipment. (Out-of-PDF, but related to computer hardware and reliable operation discussed implicitly by first-gen computer issues on Page 108)

text: The development of 'wearable technology' like smartwatches and fitness trackers is an example of progress in:

options.text: ICT, particularly in mobile and embedded systems

explanation: Wearable technology involves electronic devices worn on the body, often incorporating sensors and connectivity, which falls under the broad umbrella of ICT advancements, especially in mobile, embedded systems, and IoT. (Out-of-PDF, example of 'new direction of progress')

text: Which of these is a potential societal benefit of widespread ICT adoption in education?

options.text: Enhanced access to diverse learning resources and personalized learning experiences.
Higher costs for educational materials for all students.

explanation: ICT in education can provide access to a vast array of online resources, interactive tools, and platforms that can support personalized learning paths for students. (Out-of-PDF, considering the chapter's title 'new direction of progress')

text: What is the primary characteristic of a surface that acts as a mirror?

options.text: It absorbs all light incident on it.
It transmits all light incident on it.
It reflects light and creates clear images.
It scatters light in all directions.

explanation: A mirror is a reflecting surface that reflects light and creates clear images. (Page 115)

text: An image formed by a plane mirror is always:
explanation: The image formed by a plane mirror is virtual (cannot be obtained on a screen) and erect. (Page 116)

text: If two plane mirrors are kept parallel to each other, how many images of an object placed between them will be formed?
explanation: When mirrors are parallel, the angle A = 0. Using the formula n = (360/A) - 1, if A approaches 0, n approaches infinity. (Page 117)

text: The phenomenon where the right side of an object appears as the left side in its image formed by a plane mirror is known as:
explanation: The image of a word appears laterally inverted in the mirror. This is called lateral inversion. (Page 117)

text: What is the minimum height of a plane mirror required for a person to see their full image?
explanation: In order to see the full image of a person standing in front of a mirror, the minimum height of the mirror must be half the height of the person. (Page 117)

text: A spherical mirror whose reflecting surface is curved inwards is called a:
explanation: If the inner surface of the spherical mirror is the reflecting surface, then it is called a concave mirror. (Page 119)

text: The centre of the sphere of which the mirror is a part is called the:
explanation: The centre of the sphere of which the mirror is a part, is called the centre of curvature of the mirror. (Page 119)

text: What is the relationship between the focal length (f) and the radius of curvature (R) of a spherical mirror?
explanation: The focal length (f) is half of the radius of curvature of the mirror. (Page 119)

text: According to the rules for drawing reflected rays, if an incident ray is parallel to the principal axis of a concave mirror, the reflected ray:

options.text: Passes through the centre of curvature
Is parallel to the incident ray

explanation: Rule 1: If an incident ray is parallel to the principal axis then the reflected ray passes through the principal focus. (Page 120)

text: If an incident ray passes through the centre of curvature of a spherical mirror, the reflected ray:

options.text: Becomes parallel to the principal axis
Is reflected at an angle of 90 degrees

explanation: Rule 3: If an incident ray passes through the centre of curvature of the mirror, the reflected ray traces the same path back. (Page 120)

text: When an object is placed at the centre of curvature of a concave mirror, the image formed is:

options.text: At the focus, real, inverted, and diminished
At the centre of curvature, real, inverted, and same size
Beyond the centre of curvature, real, inverted, and magnified
Between pole and focus, virtual, erect, and magnified

explanation: When the object is at the centre of curvature, the image is formed at the centre of curvature, is inverted, real, and of the same size as the object. (Page 122)

text: An image formed by a convex mirror is always:
explanation: The image formed by a convex mirror is always virtual, smaller than the object (diminished), and situated behind the mirror, and erect. (Page 123)

text: Which type of mirror is also known as a focusing mirror because parallel rays get focused after reflection?
explanation: A concave mirror is also called a focusing mirror. This is because, as shown in figure 11.14 A, parallel rays get focused after reflection in this mirror. (Page 123)

text: A convex mirror is also called a dispersing mirror because:

options.text: It focuses parallel rays to a point.
Parallel incident rays get dispersed after reflection.

explanation: A convex mirror is also called a dispersing mirror. This is because, as shown in figure 11.14 B, parallel incident rays get dispersed after reflection in this mirror. (Page 124)

text: Which of the following is a common use of a concave mirror?

options.text: Shaving mirror or dental hospital mirror
Reflector in street lights for spreading light

explanation: Concave mirrors are used in barber shops and dental hospitals. If the object is placed between the pole and focus of the mirror, an erect, virtual and magnified image is obtained. (Page 125)

text: According to the Cartesian sign convention, the object is always kept:

options.text: To the right of the mirror
To the left of the mirror

explanation: The object is always kept on the left of the mirror. (Page 125)

text: The mirror formula relating object distance (u), image distance (v), and focal length (f) is:
explanation: The relationship between the object distance (u), image distance (v) and the focal length (f) is called the mirror formula: 1/v + 1/u = 1/f. (Page 125)

text: Magnification (M) produced by a spherical mirror is given by M = h₂/h₁, where h₂ is the height of the image and h₁ is the height of the object. It can also be expressed as:
explanation: Magnification M = Height of the image (h₂) / Height of the object (h₁). From this it can be shown that M = -v/u. (Page 126)

text:
Assertion (A): A convex mirror is used as a rear-view mirror in vehicles.
Reason (R): Convex mirrors have a wider field of view and always form an erect, diminished image.

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

explanation: Convex mirrors are used as rear-view mirrors because they provide a wider field of view and form erect, virtual, and diminished images of objects behind the vehicle, making them suitable for this purpose. (Page 124, 125)

text:
Consider the following statements regarding image formation by a concave mirror:
1. When the object is at infinity, the image is formed at the focus.
2. When the object is between the pole and focus, a virtual and magnified image is formed.
3. When the object is at the focus, the image is formed at infinity and is highly magnified.
How many of these statements are true?
explanation: Statement 1 is true (object at very large distance, image at focus). Statement 2 is true (virtual, erect, magnified behind mirror). Statement 3 is true (image at infinity, inverted, real, very large). (Page 122)

text: A ray of light is incident on a plane mirror at an angle of 30° with the mirror surface. What is the angle of reflection?
explanation: The angle of incidence is the angle between the incident ray and the normal. If the angle with the mirror surface is 30°, then the angle of incidence is 90° - 30° = 60°. According to the laws of reflection, the angle of reflection equals the angle of incidence, so it is 60°. (Page 115, basic laws)

text: The focal length of a spherical mirror is 20 cm. What is its radius of curvature?
explanation: The focal length (f) is half of the radius of curvature (R), so R = 2f. Given f = 20 cm, R = 2 * 20 cm = 40 cm. (Page 119)

text: Which property of light is primarily responsible for the formation of images by mirrors?
explanation: Mirrors form images due to the reflection of light from their surfaces. (Page 115)

text: If an object is placed between the focus and the centre of curvature of a concave mirror, the image formed will be:
explanation: When the object is placed between the focus and centre of curvature, the image is formed beyond the centre of curvature, is real, inverted, and magnified. (Page 122, Fig 11.11 A)

text: The pole (P) of a spherical mirror is:

options.text: The centre of the sphere from which the mirror is a part.
The point where parallel rays converge or appear to diverge from.
The geometric centre of the reflecting surface of the mirror.
The midpoint between the centre of curvature and the focus.

explanation: The centre of the mirror surface is called its pole. P is the pole of the mirror in figure 11.7. (Page 119)

text: For a real image formed by a spherical mirror, the magnification is generally considered:
explanation: For real images, the height of the image (h₂) is taken as negative (as they are usually inverted). Since the height of the object (h₁) is positive, M = h₂/h₁ will be negative. (Page 126)

text: What type of image cannot be obtained on a screen?
explanation: A virtual image is formed when reflected rays do not actually meet but appear to come from a point behind the mirror; such an image cannot be obtained on a screen. (Page 116, 124)

text: A concave mirror produces a magnified, virtual image when the object is placed:

options.text: Between the pole and the principal focus

explanation: When an object AB is placed between the pole and focus of the concave mirror, the image is behind the mirror, erect, virtual, and larger than the object. (Page 122, Fig 11.11 B)

text: The scientist Justus von Liebig is credited with:

options.text: Coating a plane glass surface with silver metal to make the first mirror.

explanation: The German scientist Justus von Liebig coated the plane surface of a piece of ordinary glass with silver metal and made the first mirror. (Page 115)

text:
Consider the following statements:
1. The image formed by a convex mirror is always smaller than the object.
2. A concave mirror can form both real and virtual images.
3. The focal length of a plane mirror is infinite.
Which of the above statements are true?
explanation: 1. Convex mirrors always form diminished virtual images. (Page 123) 2. Concave mirrors form real images when the object is beyond F, and a virtual image when the object is between P and F. (Page 122) 3. A plane mirror can be considered a spherical mirror with an infinite radius of curvature, hence an infinite focal length. (OutOfPDF, but logically derived from R=2f)

text:
Assertion (A): The image formed by a plane mirror is at the same distance behind the mirror as the object is in front of it.
Reason (R): The reflected rays from a plane mirror appear to diverge from a point behind the mirror.

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

explanation: Both statements are true characteristics of image formation by a plane mirror. However, the fact that rays appear to diverge (making it virtual) doesn't directly explain why the distances are equal; the equal distance is a geometric consequence of the laws of reflection. (Page 116)

text: If an object is placed 30 cm in front of a plane mirror, the image is formed:

options.text: 30 cm in front of the mirror

explanation: The perpendicular distance of the image from the mirror is equal to the perpendicular distance of the source from the mirror. (Page 116)

text: The number of images (n) formed by two plane mirrors inclined at an angle A is given by the formula n = (360°/A) - 1. If A = 60°, what is n?
A spherical mirror whose reflecting surface is curved outwards is called a:
explanation: If the outer surface of the spherical mirror is the reflecting surface then it is called a convex mirror. (Page 119)

text: The straight line passing through the pole and the centre of curvature of a spherical mirror is called:
explanation: The straight line passing through the pole and centre of curvature of the mirror is called its principal axis. (Page 119)

text: If an incident ray passes through the principal focus of a concave mirror, the reflected ray:

options.text: Passes through the centre of curvature
Is parallel to the principal axis

explanation: Rule 2: If an incident ray passes through the principal focus of the mirror, the reflected ray is parallel to the principal axis. (Page 120)

text: When an object is placed at the focus of a concave mirror, the image is formed at:

options.text: Between focus and centre of curvature

explanation: When the object is at the focus, the image is formed at infinity, is inverted, real, and very large. (Page 122)

text: Which type of mirror is used in flood lights to produce a bright beam of light?
explanation: Concave mirrors are used in flood lights. The source of light is placed a little beyond the centre of curvature of the mirror. This gives a bright beam of light. (Page 125)

text: According to Cartesian sign convention, distances measured towards the right of the pole are taken as:
